title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: After being criticized for his "soapy" second season of the British television series, Julian Fellowes takes us back to a much slower pace in Downton, full of the lovely little things that made the first season so delightful... and then crushes us.Criticisms of this series' predictability and tired plot twists notwithstanding, this season is less problematic with its twists than previous ones. But we still can't escape the never-ending drudgery of poor Edith, who is thwarted at every turn. I sincerely hope the writer gives her a break someday! Just when one possibility of future happiness turns up, Fellowes throws in a plot twist right out of a Bronte novel to further complicate her life. There's also a redundancy and lack of clarity in certain plot twists (such as Anna's sudden realization of Vera Bates' motives, which were obvious to us all last season). But it's always funny, always charming, and always romantic... even if it does make us cry buckets of tears before the season is out. It threatens to take one character from us, only to deviate into two shocking, unexpected deaths in a later episode.As always, the acting is magnificent and this season there's a lot to work with emotionally, from a death to near financial disaster and the arrival of a newborn to Downton. Maggie Smith is given all the best lines but the flirtations between Matthew and Mary are delightful to watch. In fact, there's one sneaked kiss in the first episode that is particularly fun. BUT, frankly, the last two minutes of this series are the most depressing I've ever seen. It ruined my Christmas, and have convinced me not only never to watch that episode again, but not to buy any of the seasons beyond this one. Pack the hankies, fans... you'll need them.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I had no interest in what I (mistakenly) assumed to be a stuffy, English TV series. Maybe just as well that I ignored the show for its first four seasons, because I've been binge-watching over the past weeks. I haven't been hooked on a network series in more years than I can remember, but this is no ordinary series. I've grown to know and love most of the characters, and loathe a few; teared up over the loss of some, and quietly cheered when one of the minor characters exacted well-deserved revenge on another.The setting for this program is simply impressive. Love much of the camerawork, too, although I'm betting that most viewers won't realize why they feel like they're walking into the abbey along with visitors during the opening sequences of many episodes.I'll admit it: I love this program, and hope it will continue for many more seasons.
summary: Don't let the title scare you off!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I heard about this program over dinner on Christmas and watched an episode on DVD.  Like a speckled trout in a Scottish stream I was hooked.  Now I am caught up on the story and just killing time until January 5, 2014 at nine o'clock in the evening.  I am really hoping that Benny Hill shows up at the Abbey for dinner but that is really the only plot suggestion I have.  Beyond that everything is perfect.  Oh yeah, the costumes are to die for. Also, they ought to get a different color car to drive past the London walkup during the transitions.  Anyone else notice that?  Probably a product of watching thirty something episodes in three days.  You get to know the cars.  In Detroit you gotta' know the pies.  At Downton Abbey you gotta' know the cars.I loved it.  No really, I did!Which actor gets the most residuals?  Let me know please.  it should be the Butler.Oh the product streamed as smoothly as a Scottish brook in the early spring sunshine.
summary: Classiest Soap Opera on Record, and British to Boot.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I would have given this version of Season 3 5 stars but:  My rating is not a reflection on the movie content but with the packaging which includes commercials.  I also have seasons 1 and 2 that I purchased directly from the UK which are region free and those disks do not have annoying and time-wasting commercials on them and instead go promptly to the main menu.  This season 3 put out with the PBS logo on it was release here in the US has at least two commercials for PBS - it's like watching the series on television with the commercials.  However, you can fast-forward to the main menu to select the episodes.  However, I will not purchase season 4 when it becomes available from the US/PBS version for the same reason that it will most likely have commercial messages in it.  Seek out the UK version instead if that matters to you. I think it's a bit arrogant on the part of PBS (and other movie studios as well), to insert commercials into a Blu-ray or DVD.  After all, one purchases movies on Blu-ray and DVD not just for the quality and convenience but for the absence of time-wasting and annoying commercials.As for the actual season 3 (and 1 and 2) of Downton Abbey, well, it's "simply fabulous" as Thurston Howell III (from the 70's TV series "Gilligan's Island", played by Jim Baccus) would say in his Dink accent, and if you've seen seasons 1 and 2 you'll not want to miss season 3.  I can't wait for season 4.  The end of season 3 was simply riveting.One gets a true sense of what it must have been like to be part of a family of Lords around the turn of the 19th century in England and to have been brought up with the attendant privileges of such a station in life there.If I were rating just the production of Downton Abbey it would get a 10 on a scale of 1 to 5 - it's that good; actors, acting, scenery, costumes, dialog, filming, character development, and especially the filming.  After the 2nd or 3rd episode you'll be hooked.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I do not watch TV at all and very few movies...I gave this a shot as so many people love it.Such a pretty show!!However, I noticed if it hadn't had such a beautiful setting, clothes and people.. I wouldn't have given the story/drama  a minute.I thought the story line was way short of the "MASTERPIECE" as titled.I  sometimes wondered how the actors took the series seriously.  Cheap tricks every few minutes... repeat behaviors when expected.I was grateful when Thomas and O'Brian showed merit over time but the other characters..meh...So its fun, addictive and isnt something I can imagine presented as a Masterpiece.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Very well done. I can actually feel and experience the period as I get to know each character.  It is hard to believe, however, that people of that time were so slow to show their true emotions.  Be that as it may, this series takes you through extreme anger, happiness, and whole range of emotions.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Probably little to say here that hasn't been said, highly recommended it for its breadth of story and fine portrayals.  The HD aspect of it is genuine, the clarity of color and detail are brilliant.Downton Abbey's sucess in the US is well documented and for all its depictions of vintage British class discrepancies its true measure of fascination for it are the storyline and interpersonal relationships.At the heart of it are how rapid social change takes place: who adapts and who doesn't?  The time here is pre and post WWI but, like Gone With The Wind, it could be about any modern era where a European based social structure goes topsy turvy. We observe the genteel nature of certain daily ritual that so obviously represents an imperialist attitude that doesn't serve all, yet, they are strangely nostalgic and idealistic. Even many of the servants say as much.But a nice shell game is being played out here between beauty and ugliness, with a seemingly slow pace depicting idle pleasure mixed with major undercurrents of displeasure, anger, sadness and bitterness.  Upstairs, downstairs, and where the twain shall meet. Human drama all the time...It's quite well done.
summary: A shell game of a story paced brilliantly

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: What starts to throw me off in the series is the tendency to make it all ok. Bad stuff happens because accidents happen (and the season finale is the most representative moment of this), but conflicts between characters seem to be less and less developed, and more thrown towards petty little discussions that eventually amount to no actual plot development. Granny is still the most interesting character in the show for me... and this is very telling as well, since she is the one who seems to have no arc of herself, rather, she seems to intervene in other plots to solve them.It was mostly a disappointing season, but the way things are set up at the end are promising, unless writing keeps taking the show towards this "all is well between good people", and keeps avoiding fissures within the house.

review_text: I will be sending my DVD collection for Season 3 back to Amazon, and hoping for a refund!I had watched seasons 1 and 2 on DVD and had read that the "full UK version" was more complete than what was aired on PBS.  I began watching season 3 on PBS, but ordered the DVD set to be delivered upon release, anxious to watch the episodes in their entirety.  Well, not only is it not the "full UK edition", it's not even the full US edition! title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Never before has the clash of cultures and times played such an integral part, as the family is beginning to show division between those willing to adjust to change and those staunchly holding onto the old ways, even between spouses.  Dear Mrs. Levinson, Cora's mother, serves here to boldly state the issue.  The idealists/diehards emerge as the Dowager Countess, Lord Grantham, Lady Mary and Mr. Carson. Their position, though sympathetic due to attachment to their characters, is an increasingly difficult one to defend.The big changes in the opening Series 3 episode are the financial loss of the family and the introduction of Cora's mother coming for the wedding, with that blunt and indomitable personality.  To my viewing, she definitely daunts the Dowager, trumping her in audacity in nearly every encounter.  No doubt the financial vulnerability plays a strong part in that. It may be a case of whether you prefer blunt over acidity or vice versa.The attachment between Matthew and Mary was never so poignant as revealed in the night before wedding sequence at Mary's bedroom door.  Matthew is so richly warm as he affirms his love and repeats to Mary the words from Tom Branson that he could not be content in life without her, regardless of their disagreement.  So effective.The mystery still holds concerning Bates, as a darker side is showing up with his cell mate.  Since he has been so insistent in not revealing things to shield others in the past, perhaps that is still the case. I wouldn't be surprised if Anna's probings provide necessary evidence and we find that again, he has been acting in honor by not revealing something that could have cleared him.  As to his cell mate, the pressure of his circumstances could well account for his unwillingness to take anything off someone he doesn't have to.  A lot of good people believe in his character.This episode as seen on PBS severely breaks the smooth transition of story lines previously experienced, making a complete UK edition mandatory.  Hopefully, there will be help in the very rapid moving from one story line to the next, as presently it is a bit of a whiplash at times.  One is trying to digest what was just presented, but is immediately being thrown into another diverse and complicated scenario.  Before, the difference in the broadcast and full version was an abrupt introduction of a character without the lead up in the full edition, but now it is more a hurl from one venue to another, especially in the latter part.It will be very interesting to see how this central theme of change plays out among the parties, along with the various fates hanging in the balance and old scores to be settled.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Excellent! Subtly and nuanced acting are the hallmarks of this series. I'd suggest that young people view this to experience acting at a sophisticated, well-schooled level;  in contrast to standard television fare. When I say sophisticated, I do not mean because the plot line centers around a upper class family. IT IS ABOUT THE QUALITY OF THE ACTING PERFORMANCES. Television can do so much better that "The Housewives of ...........". It is one thing to argue this case and  quite another thing to experience the differences. Indeed, if you've never experienced excellence, then junk can pass as good.
summary: The acting is of the first order; so much conveyed via subtly and nuance.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: As Season Three ends, maybe it is getting a little bit soapy, but it still offers some of the best character portraits ever seen on TV.  British Drama has always been based on character and a feel for how language can demonstrate character.  Americans have a lot of character, but American screen writers have forgotten how to demonstrate it through speech.  Recently, we inadvertently watched an episode of I Claudius (highly-regarded BBC series about a Roman emporer's family), and observed that the Downton menial servants seem to demonstrate more character on a daily basis than the Emperor Augustus.
summary: Simply the Best TV has To Offer

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I have to admit that I am addicted to Downton Abbey.  It took hold of me in Episode 1, Season 1 and has continued.  Of course, I will admit that I was a history major.  Downton Abbey is one of those well written pieces that does not alter history and reports it in a palatable manner easy for the non history lover to digest, an art developed by Mitchner.  I undertand that American television, NBC I think, has hired the DA writer to put together a similar saga based in early 1900s New York.  If that interests you, you might want to watch The Age Innocence, starring Daniel Day Lewis and based on the book by Edith Wharton.
summary: Super writing, acting, and deivery of history.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: We love Downton Abbey and strongly recommend the series to one and all.What I don't recommend is that you buy/download the Amazon version.  We missed episode 1 of series 3 on our DVR and decided to download it from Amazon.  The version they showed was notably different from the other shows and it didn't exactly fit in some ways.  Come to learn, after the fact, that the Amazon version of episode 1 is only 1 hour 7 minutes long while the official PBS version is 1 hour 52 minutes.  If you care about Downton Abbey I strongly recommend that you look elsewhere for your media lest you, like us, are forever wondering what happened in the missing 45 minutes.
summary: Amazon's Downton Videos are Heavily Edited!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: What can I say? Signing up for Prime on Amazon was totally worth it just to be able to watch all of the Downton Abbey Seasons! I absolutely love watching this show and following the characters thru the twists and turns of the early 20th century in England. It embodies everything a good drama should have, at times it's funny, sad, touching, thought provoking, amusing, and it leaves you wanting more.It's also something that the whole family can watch without being embarrassed in front of your kids or having to turn the channel. It takes you back to a simpler time and yet you see that people had to handle some of the same issues as we have today. Highly recommended if you love period drama.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: this episode was especially moving.  and, in another review, I objected to some of the silliness and occasional incongruities of plot and script ("learning curve," an expression used in this episode, is not an expression that one would have heard in England in 1920).  but, the acting is consistently marvelous and the direction is always interesting.  then again, the character of Cora's mother was artlessly constructed to be a repellent cartoon figure, crass, impolite, and devoid of any redeeming traits. a gentle or not so gentle point about the differences between the American nouveaux riches or Americans generally and the English nobility which had been made more delicately would have been more effective and more credible.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: An above average period piece.  Basically, another "Upstairs/Downstairs" type drama showing the machinations of running a large country estate.  It follows several story lines...from the family, to the staff...so does well to keep your attention.  The "house" is the star, and the characters flow through it as history marches on.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I was so touched at the closeness between the family and staff. This was not an ordinary employer/ employee relationship, but more a very close familial one in which the objective was protection of each other.
summary: A must see for fans of the gentler life of English country life.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I missed out on Downton Abbey,  and am a recent convert.  I started watching it because my wife loves some of the British classics, like Pride and Prejudice, etc.  I soon was enthralled with the ins and outs of the life at Downton, and the accurate historical aspects of the show.  Lastly, though it is a true drama, it is threaded with that ever so funny British humor, which my wife and I love.If you try it for a few episodes, you will get hooked and brought into the lives of some wonderfully developed characters.  I purchased the first six episodes of Season 3, so that my wife and I may be caught up into the present of the lives of the characters of Downton Abbey.I highly recommend this series, if you can't tell.
summary: One (if not the) best show on television!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is such a good story and I enjoy the period in which it is set very much. The depiction of a traditional way of life for the landed gentry in England giving way to more modern patterns of life is fascinating.  I can't evaluate the historical accuracy of much of what is depicted but I think within general historical parameters it is a good attempt.  The story is rich in human struggle, failure, recovery and sometimes success.  The intricate relationships between the servants and the served are worth some serious consideration.  If serious consideration is too much work on a given evening watching can just be fun.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: We loved season 3 until the final episode where they kill Matthew. Why do producers feel the necessity to be killing off the heroes they have developed? It's a horrible thing to do to the viewers.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is a character-driven epic that draws you in, twists your nose, and shakes your emotions. This is the best Brit-import I've ever watched. Some of the situations may be a bit contrived and manipulated, but the characters -- the script and the acting -- hold me from beginning to the end.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey is filled with the rich touches of subtle acting and carefully rehearsed movements.  There is no flash and sudden violence or overdone special effects.  This is drama in the careful style that leads one to the emotions, intrigue, and awareness of a world changing so rapidly that all the characters are striving to keep up with the events in which they are involved.  It is the best of television drama.
summary: The Subtle Touches of British Drama

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I had so many folk tell me to watch and sometimes I do. And there have been times when I have smiled, or even been touched by an episode. But that said, DA is not afraid to retread over some of the most tired soap opera chestnuts to move its story from one episode to the next. There are some reasons to watch it--Maggie Smith's delivery, Thomas' struggles and some insight into class, activism and feminism between the wars come to mind. But on the whole it is predictable and sometimes dreadful as it teeters between good and predictable.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I'm stunned that the DVD has omitted scenes from the broadcast version shown in the United States.  As several reviewers have noted, in Part 6 (which was episode 5 shown in the states, since the USA broadcast combined Parts 1 and 2 from the DVD into a single episode), the crucial scene where Mrs. O'Brien tells Thomas how much the new footman James has taken a liking to him is NOT on the DVD.  Another example is in Part 4 (episode 3 in the states)where Daisy tells Mr. Mason that she is interested in another footman (Alfred), but that scene is omitted in the DVD although it is shown in the TV episode.  I'm fairly certain other scenes have been omitted since each part on the DVD runs shorter than the episode that was shown on TV.  I was not a regular viewer of the series until I purchased the DVD of seasons 1 and 2, and I watched all the episodes over a month's time so I could be prepared for season 3.  I was completely enthralled by the series and I eagerly looked forward to the new season.  But now I am extremely disappointed by the DVDs, and I wonder how much I missed by not watching the series on TV.  The DVDs are promoted by PBS, and the network should be embarrassed that the DVDs show edited episodes.  Also shame should go to Amazon for promoting the DVD as the "uncut" UK version.  So I'll now only use my DVR to watch the remaining episodes.
summary: The DVD is NOT the uncut UK broadcast version as promoted by Amazon.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Season 3 of this series is the best of all.  The storyline is powerful and moving.  The cast is incredible. This ensemble of actors is second to none.  From starring roles to the most minor of characters, each actor inhabits his or her character with such skill and talent, that it's hard to believe the characters aren't real, breathing human beings from the early 20th century.  I'm a big Maggie Smith fan so I'm not surprised that she is magnificent as the dowager countess, after all she's not Dame Maggie Smith for nothing, but every other actor in this cast also gives a sensitive, nuanced performance in every episode.Of course, none of this would be possible without some of the best writing on television.  From storyline to dialogue to character development to historical detail, the writing makes it seem that not a word is out of place.  Unlike some other multi-episode family sagas of the past TV seasons, there is nothing sprawling or extraneous about the way the story evolves.  Tight direction and editing make certain each episode flows smoothly and effortlessly.  Add to that , a beautiful setting, great production values and costume design and you have the makings of one of the finest series ever seen on television.If you are not watching this series, you are missing out on something truly special.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: It is a compelling story that stays with one long after the last episode.  The story and the acting are very well done.  I'm looking forward to the next season, certainly.The only disappointment I could voice about the series is that it was clearly used as a platform for airing some modern moral views that were not, to my understanding, representative of that day.  These views came out, briefly in the first and third seasons, and while reprehensible to me, they did not spoil the story at large....for me as an adult.  However, I would not recommend those episodes, in particular, for young audiences because of them.  In truth, there are several more "adult" episodes I would not have my children watch, good and appropriate as the series, as a whole, is.
summary: Over all well done adult series

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I could not wait until I could see the next episode.  I loved every bit of it.  The period costumes, the furnishings and the distinction of social classes were so interesting. The exploration of the period before, during and after World War I and it's impact on British society was very enlightening.  I l loved the way they shed light on the effect of war on the soldiers suffering from post traumatic stress and the wives who lost their husbands due to war.  Great series, I tell all my friends to watch it. Can't wait until season 4.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is a 5 star series (just like some 12K+ others have rated it).  That said, personally I really dislike how so many movies and shows have to go with a Greek Tragedy model these days and some really good characters have to "die" (though I realize some of the actors and actresses are reported as saying they asked to leave the show...hmm, I wonder why so many)?  That's my only critique really - but the acting is superb almost all the time and I enjoy the rich fodder of subjects that can be historically portrayed, explored and put on display to understand all the radical life style and changes that societies underwent thru the first few decades of the 20th century. Thank you Masterpiece Theater.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I am so glad I got amazon prime so I could watch the Downton abbey episodes in order from the beginning. What an amazing show!  The characters are mesmerizing, the storyline is fascinating, the scenery is gorgeous! This show shows the differences in the classes in England in the early 1900 s.  The upper class is so excessive in every way! But so proud of their heritage and lifestyle.  They find it difficult to move ahead with the changes after WW 1, changes  including a declining fortune and increasing women's lib. I was so impressed by the lower class, the staff at Downton abbey. There are classes among the lower class! The butler lords it over the others, they even stand up when he enters the room! Each staff member has his particular job and he/she works  so hard to move up in the ranks. Then there is interdependence between the two classes, each needing the other. This is an amazing show. I would give it 10 stars!

review_text: Downton Abbey is a terrific series and season 3 is no exception.  The show is well-written and has great music and acting.  It is also set within a strong historical context.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: In the real world, people are born, fall in love, marry, and die according to their stars and not by the exigencies of the actors. The beauty of Downton Abbey is you feel the randomness of life within their best laid plans. Being a breast cancer survivor, I appreciated the glimpse into how that situation may have played out in the early years of the 20th century. Having a gay sister and a brother, also gay, who died of AIDs, I very much appreciated how far we have come. And, being a hopeless romantic, I appreciate the restrained beauty of the many interactions, both platonic and amorous. But most of all, I love watching Maggie Smith chew up the scenery, whether riding in the back of the limo or walking across the room after the death of her granddaughter. What a gal!
summary: What can I say. It's Downton Abbey

review_text: I didn't think I would like this series. I thought it would be stuffy and boring. But I thoroughly enjoyed it. After binge watching all four seasons I had a bit of separation anxiety. I also enjoyed the upstairs characters, especially, Cybil, Branson, Edith and oh that wonderful Matthew. I do love Maggie Smith in any role and Mrs. Crawley, Matthews mom is also a big favorite. I just can't wait for season five.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This series is thoroughly  invested with richly portrayed characters and faithful renderings of the life and times of one British upper class family and their servants, relatives and neighbors..  It follows the characters of this household  going through the vicissitudes of country life following the economic woes of  post-WWI England, and the social changes that begin to slowly blur the lines between the landed gentry and the servant class.  Also it touches on the Irish "troubles", women's rights, and the re-structuring of the tenant farmers' contributions to the estate of Downton Abbey,  We watch as each class of persons reacts to the social, economic, and moral changes brought on by the  aftermath of a world war..I highly recommend everyone to watch this series....even those who have difficulty understanding the King's English.  The brogue is easily understood in Downton Abbey and should be a comfortable, but soul-satisfying introduction the glory of  BBC productions.
summary: An Absolutely Stunning Offering by the BBC's Masterpiece Theatre.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The third season of Downton Abbey, which takes place in the early 1920s, has some good times -- chief amongst those Matthew and Mary's long-awaited wedding -- and some very bad times indeed, which I won't go into here. The acting continues to be good and I agree with most of the plot points, but of course there are a couple of really bad situations that I don't want to give away but that most people have probably heard about anyway. The ending of this season was far darker than that of season two, so I'm hoping there are happier times ahead in season four. Production values are good and the costumes are sumptuous.
summary: Some tough times in this third season

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is a good choice if you're looking for a new series with your wife/husband.  Both my wife and I enjoyed watching this very much.  The acting and production quality are great and they do a good job of taking you into that time period.  It's for adults not kids, but it is something that will appeal to the young and old adults alike.  At times it's fun and at times it's sad.I still give it 5 starts, but there is one bad thing I can say about this series - the ending was very disappointing and didn't really fit with the rest of the show (Don't worry, not a spoiler). Some comments from the writers suggest it's some sort of British tradition and we have seen similar things on other British shows. I speculate that it has more to do with the personal careers of the writers than it does on the story - so it unfortunately leaves you with a bad taste in your mouth.  So either don't watch the final episode, or take it with a very large grain of salt.  Maybe even just think of your own alternative ending before you watch the final episode and try to envision that when you get mad at the show :)Happy Watching!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Bravo! Mr. Fellowes, creator and writer, is a mastermind using actors/characters as delicate pieces in an exquisite Masterpiece. After viewing a special on Manor of Castles” which focused on Highclere Castle the filming location of show and show’s title “Downton Abbey, I realized this was a must-see PBS Masterpiece Classic. Amazon Prime Members- Kindle owners, as stated in “Downton Abbey” are of the “privileged,” I was able to watch all three seasons for “FREE!”During winter break was spent watching all three season , Mr. Fellows much like Hitchcock  can be  deliciously evil to his characters, as well as to his audience. He manages to touch on every subject from breast cancer to homosexuality. As he has Mr. Carson, the Head Butler state when the suggestion of firing Mr. Barrows for being open about his sexuality, “I can’t fire the poor creature for being born that way.” Throughout this series Mr. Fellows manages to convince “Lady and Gentlemen Viewers” to fall in love with the romance of castles, dresses and even accept women were to be witless creatures-“seen and not heard.” Genius, the talent to keep us on the edge of our seats every show with humorous characters, proving  beautiful and handsome are all in the eyes of the beholder, the series manages to fascinatingly use English history as a character.BEWARE VIEWERS! Mr. Fellowes does use his English wit and sarcasm to tittle viewers in every scene, while characters romantically are falling in love and tragically dying.  Viewers will fall in love with all of the cast members- DON”T!  Unlike other television drama series- Mr. Fellowes has no problem killing a main character off! A  CAUTION WARNING -“Downton Abbey” is unforgivingly additive.
summary: CAUTION WARNING -“Downton Abbey” is unforgivingly additive.!

These fictional characters made real history come alive for me. I imagined the world as it was when my grandmother was born, and finally started to understand why she was who she was. An excellent series!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey succeeds where other series have failed because it is intelligently written and compellingly acted. Part of its appeal of course lies in recreating a bygone time that many of us Americans are curious about, like our British brethren. It breathes life into an age of pomp and circumstance, that we may not have realized was as alive as it is here. The Crawley family have for ages lived in splendor, and their servants in a lower station in life, but there's a conscious realization that everyone, the rich and the servants, have a  role to play. Indeed, Carson the head butler is proud of his station, and has no hesitation in enforcing the rules with all the staff under his command. This system works because, at least in this household, the Earl's family care about the staff and their well-being, as part of the social compact that makes everything work.This brings a basic humanity to their lives and enables the stories to bring real flesh and personality to the characters. The romantic but ultimately tragic courtship between Mary Crawley and Matthew Crawley (distant cousins) matters to us not just the fluff of soap opera, but we see their torn inner lives and the reconciliation they make to finally accept and love each other. I think Hugh Bonneville is especially effective as Lord Crawley. A benevolent master who rules but knows much is expected of him, he accepts Bates, a semi-invalid veteran who fought with him in the Boer War, as his new valet despite the infighting it causes with other footmen. At a crucial moment in season three, Lord Crawley graciously cedes operating control of his estate to his son-in-laws, fighting the impulse to feel usurped.Like many serials, Downton Abbey contrives events to conform around it's characters. SPOILER ALERT: it seems to me the only reason to kill off Matthew in a car accident is the actor Dan Stevens was ready to leave the show. Still, these things happen with any long-lived show, and the scripts create plenty enough genuine intrigue and action without it.There is so much more you could say to praise Downton Abbey. It's addictiveness to the viewer (like me) is it makes you care about all the members of the household...plus it packs so much into each episode, you can barely miss half an hour before being completely lost in what's happening next.
summary: The utmost in intelligent continuing series - turns the model on its head

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This contains a mild spoiler, but no real details.I am surprised that I find myself giving this wonderful series anything less than a 5-star rating.  After viewing the final episode of Season 3, I was inclined to rate this lower, but just couldn't do it.I am trying to be careful not to write a "spoiler" but after the birth of Sybl's baby (and that is all I will say) I began to have the sense that I was watching a soap opera. Then events surrounding Tom and Jimmy and now, the ending of the final episode, have continued to give that sense.  The series has been cheapened.The wonderful actors and characters, the costumes, beautiful settings both indoors and out, impeccable attention to period details and manners -- so much has made this series a terrific treat - a feast, really, but the art that this series represents is compromised by heavy handedness with the script.I wasn't expecting a fairy tale where nothing tragic ever happens and all live happily ever after, but this series did not present itself to become an emotional roller coaster.  It goes against the grain of all the other features of the viewing experience.  The events have begun to feel contrived.I am relieved that the season is over, wishing that somehow, the ending was all a mistake -- but glad for a break from it.  I am disappointed that I am not eagerly looking forward to Season 4, although of course I will watch it.  Cautiously.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Finally Lady Mary & Michael are together! Now it's Lady Edith's turn for some romance, or is it? Sybil & Branson re-join the family story which brings both joy & sorrow and a new family relation is added to the show. Downstairs a new footman joins the staff, Obrien & Thomas are no longer allies and romance & jealousy is in the air! Christmas special takes the family to Scotland so some beautiful scenery is included. The ending to the season is unfortunate but I think they handled it very nicely, leaving a lot to look forward to in season 4.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey Season 3 will keep you on the edge of your seats.  How can you not love Thomas?  I am such a sucker for the underdog!!  Thomas is great as is the actor,Rob-James Collier, who makes him come alive in this series!  Anna, my second favorite character shows strength and will that will inspire you to become a better person.  Mr. Carson, the man I vote as a living, breathing owl, is here again with wisdom and a respect for the traditional which always keeps me on a respectable path.  I don't think there is one character who doesn't please in this series.  Oh wait!  There is one.  Cora.  I could do without her sideways glances and ridiculous acting by Elizabeth McGovern.  I hate to be harsh but it's true.  She should have died when the flu hit the Downton household.  I totally understand why Lord Grantham only married her for her money.  Otherwise, this is a stellar cast, with stellar scripts!  I shall be watching this series over and over again with pure pleasure.  I even have my young, teenaged daughter hooked!
summary: I hope this series never ends!!!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: What's not to like? Downton Abbey captures all the style and grace of aristocratic England without the stuffiness one might expect from an English period piece. The characters are all unique and their story lines create a patchwork quilt of subplots that continue to draw in the audience as it moves from one story to another.A soap opera? Perhaps, but the most stylish and engaging that I've ever seen. All class and no trash.
summary: Class, style and a dynamite character roster

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Okay, I admit it--I am an Anglophile!  I'm also a huge fan of almost anything the BBC (and by extension, PBS) does.  To drink of the BBC/PBS is to drink of single malt scotch rather than the others' 'Ripple'--you know, the "flavored" soda pop wine with the screw-off lid. :-)  Specific reasons I give 5-stars to Downton Abbey:  good acting, the human condition portrayed well, excellent storyline, and so on.  I would recommend the drama to anyone who thinks like I do, as partially described above.  I appreciate an excellent series.  I have recently purchased seasons one and two and will soon purchase three and four.  I don't actually have access to television in my house, and having just repatriated myself after teaching for five years in China, without access to PBS or BBC television, am enjoying some of the better productions of same, selectively, through DVDs and VCRs, and the like--avoiding the 99% or so of the "others" (the proverbial "wasteland') as described above.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The first two and a half seasons were great, but things unravel in the third season. The plot starts to mirror a soap opera and the producers abandoned their historical narrative in favor of a comfy, modernized 1920s. But more than all of that, if the show can't convince it's biggest stars to stay on to the end of the series, how will they convince the viewers to keep watching as the show kills off main characters whose actors are heading for greener pastures? It looks like they might crawl across the finish line. Too bad, because it started as a great series.
summary: After a good run, the wheels come off

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I find the history shown though the eyes of those who were living at the time to be much more interesting than reading the history in a book. I have become very involved in the story of both upstairs and downstairs and the interaction of both sets of characters. The personality traits shown continue in society today in various ways that fit the times in which we live. It seems it doesn't matter what period in which you are living, people remain the same.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I will let the other reviewers speak to the show itself, but I wanted to make a point about the quality of the Blu-Ray release.  I watched the other seasons of this show on Netflix and had a certain expectation for the video and audio quality when I got this Blu-Ray.  I was blown away when the opening credits of the first episode rolled.  Every scene was incredibly sharp and had a range and depth of color that makes the show I watched on Netflix look like VHS.  The audio was also much improved, though I expected as much since Netflix doesn't have an advanced multi-channel audio setup.
summary: Much better than watching on Netflix

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Too much overwritten sloppy sentiment is ruining this once fine drama. The plot lines are becoming repetitive and I yearn for more than romance and vindictive servants trying to get the better of each other. Only Lady Edith's life is at all interesting. The introduction of 18 year old Rose provided some welcome relief. Perhaps they can take her character to some more jazz clubs to give a bit more fun and color.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: If you're interested in historical drama with some humor thrown in, this is the series for you. The first four seasons span ten years from 1912-1922/23. They deal with the Titanic disaster; WWI; women's rights; the plight of farmers; the realization of the aristocracy that they need to make changes in the running of their estates in order to keep up and maintain what they've had for generations; as well as dealing with rape, the lives of servants, love between classes, relationships of the "upstairs" family(there are even several mentions of how showing emotion is very un-British;-), and so much more. I had four days to myself while my family was away and I decided to give Downton Abbey a chance and I ended up watching all 30 episodes in those four days. What else can I say? The acting is superb! And excellent, excellent, excellent!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I was disappointed with the disjointed stories in Season 3 of Downton Abbey. I loved the first and second series, especially the second. I practically wore holes in my BluRays while my husband was deployed last year. By the by, he's deployed again this year and I can't stand to actually watch these episodes more than once or twice more to fill in the background while I'm doing housework. The characters aren't as engaging or likeable; we don't get to spend as much time with any of them; I can't stand Shirley MacLain. Bringing in a big name (and tragedy for the sake of tragedy for that matter) for the draw, in this case, disappoints miserably. Hoping that Season 4 is better written, more cohesive, and more intimate.
summary: Not as good as Season 1 and 2

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The acting, the set, and the drama is all top notch in this PBS masterpiece theatre production. The time period is one not often talked about nor seen on modern tv lineups. Great actors bring this show to the next level on subjects that would normally be rather boring or forgettable. The third season has many unforeseen twists and disappointments both for the characters and the viewer. Unexpected deaths and finance issues seem to be the focus of many of the episodes. Love the character development and the sympathetic emotions it pulls out of the you as you watch characters you may hate or love struggle with tough choices and situations. Great show that I recommend to anyone and everyone.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The war changes the household at Downton Abbey, even to the servants personal lives. They must look deeper within themselves, even to the servants to look for fulfillment.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: There are plenty of reviews out there explaining the virtues of this show: period sets and costumes, interesting look at a historic social structure, digging into social issues which were important at the time and continue to have strong relevance today.  The story line is a bit slow, though, and sometimes not that interesting.  Laid up with an injury, I "binge-watched" the first three seasons over 2.5 weeks.  The first one was engrossing, though the acting of the Cora character was an annoyance.  I am pretty sure that is how she is being directed to act, though, because the character itself is just as shallow and frustrating as the acting.  The second season continued to be engaging, though the speed of time passing was so quick (nearly a year per episode in some spots), that a lot of plot-drivers are left to the imagination.  The third season is pretty boring.  Same story lines, rehashed.  Maybe it is because the "world" of the show has been so thoroughly well-explained in past episodes, that there is little left to fascinate.  Maybe it is because we have found out so many hidden secrets of the characters that there is little left to surprise. Maybe it is because their world is becoming more like our modern-day one - interesting from a historical perspective but not from a televised fiction. Constant footage of two of the main characters making out.  The romance was interesting while there was some sexual tension in it, but watching married people be in love isn't interesting in itself.  Only still watching because I'm on bed rest.  By the time the 4th season is available for instant viewing, I probably won't get around to seeing it.
summary: Mostly very good, a few flaws

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Who would think that the trials and tribulations of the end, or at least a significant change, of the British aristocracy would have any relevance in 21st century America. However, it does! What are our responsibilities for local employment, employer-employee relations, and labor relations? What is the impact of technology on job destruction and job creation?That, and it is just cool to see recent history that seems so far away: women's suffrage, race relations, class mobility, and so on.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Lavish and beautiful to look at, Downtown Abbey's third season returns with the same level of drama viewers have come to expect of the Crawleys and their servants.  One of Downtown's most winning traits is how well they develop their characters and season three continues this tradition, with special focus on the characters of Tom Branson, Lady Sybil's chauffeur-turned-husband, and problems faced by Thomas, the ever wily footman.  There are fun new faces, such as Shirley McClaine, and the return of a few old ones as well.There are a few stumbling blocks; romantic rivalries between house servants feels very soapy, as does the plot line surrounding the financial future of Downtown.  But overall it's the same winning period piece fans have come to love, with some lovely moments and some heartbreaking twists before all is said and done.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Loved the acting, the costumes, the dialogue, the drama, the story lines and narrative arcs- generally all nicely interwoven. But the Thomas, Ethel and Branson story arcs are absolutely ludicrous. The Thomas plot arc in season 3 (end of) was just pure BBC propaganda. At the very least, Thomas should have been sent packing, instead he's made under butler?? what??? Thomas should have been just like Ethel was (sent packing), but the BBC falls face first on the gay sword-no surprise there. The Ethel story line was much more honest and real, then got absurd, then real again.  The Branson story line, had the BBC stayed true to Edwardian History, would have been sent packing too and daughter disowned. What's next? BBC's next version of Pride and Prejudice will have Charlotte Lucas (Or Mr. Collins) come out of the closet, Lydia smashing the entail and inheriting all of Longborne. .... and Mary Bennett will have her first born child at Longborne courtesy of AI.... boring...
summary: BBC PC Rules the Day... boring....

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Its intelligent, authentic, speaks of the issues of the time.  When I watch Downton Abbey, I am transported to the 20s in England and I can actually forget I am on my couch watching it through the internet.I long for ragtime, those flapper dresses, the jalopies and a society with so many rules to keep every person reined in.  The lower classes toiling until they go to bed, the rich who do nothing but change their clothes and travel... I don't want to live that time, but for a brief moment, I am transported and I just adore the escape from my own reality.  Well done!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: *Spoilers*The first half of Season 3 is worth watching for several poignant moments. I was especially moved by  Mrs. Hughes' storyline since I consider her the most compassionate character at Downton. When she stands framed in the shadows of the corridor and accepts that she may die, it is one of the finest shots of the series. I also loved Carson's surreptitious singing revealing just how much he loves her. Also enjoyable, though brief and thinly portrayed, is Shirley MacLaine's appearance as she brings fresh air to the stodginess of English tradition.Unfortunately, my interest waned after Sybil's moving and unexpected death in Episode Five. As the episodes progressed, Mary, Father Crawley, and Matthew grew increasingly irritating to me. The subplots reintroducing the fallen maid and the battle between Mrs. O'Brien and Thomas were tiresome and repetitive. Bates in prison and out of prison was boring. With the introduction of the silly 18-year old ingenue, the season jumped the shark. Maybe Ted McGinley was unavailable.Lastly, the season ending was dreadful. Due to his expired contract with the show, Matthew Crawley (Dan Stevens) had to die an untimely soap-opera death and, as his car plummeted, so did the series.
summary: Starts well, ends with a whimper

review_text: Unlike previous season's discs, the UK edition of Downton Abbey 3 is different than that which PBS is broadcasting. Having previously watched the UK version (while overseas) and currently watching the US as broadcast by PBS I can say that the UK edition is MISSING a few short but quite good sequences.I don't quite understand why this is but must say that it is unfortunate as some of these sequences add better continuity to the story.If you can wait for the US version, I would recommend that you wait for that version to become available.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is the most additive show I have watched in a very long time.  You get caught up in the rhythm of the individual lives of each character and you can’t look away.  I love how human each one is.  The evil is not absolute nor is the good.  Sometimes these characters do the most surprising things and that is what makes it so worth watching.In any case, I haven’t started watching Season 4 yet because I like to stream them back to back.  What has surprised me most of all is that both friends and acquaintances of mine from every end of the political and religious realms seem to be hooked on this unique show.Note to anyone reading my review; it is so worth your time.  It isn’t a typical show as seen here in the US; it is slow, rich and lovely.  It is a bit like reading a wonderful novel.  Bravo Mr. Fellowes.  Good job!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This was an extra Christmas treat!  We have had Amazon Prime for years just for the free two day shipping...especially at Christmas time.  It totally pays for itself!  No traffic, crowds, parking, or bags to deal with and I get to comparison shop online in my home with the fireplace on, wearing pajamas, and a cup of coffee!I have been wanting to watch Downton Abbey and didn't know where to go to see it...and it shows up on Amazon Prime for free!  My daughter and I watched both seasons through my son's XBox between Christmas and New Year's while it rained outside.  Totally wonderful and I had no idea this was available to us!  This HD version was great and I would tell anyone to watch this amazing series.  It is set in an era we don't see portrayed often: early 1900's when electricity, telephones, and "motor carriages" were just coming on the scene in homes...along with women's suffrage.  Can't wait for January 6th when it premieres on PBS...although, we will have to wait to watch each episode every week.  Watching the series on Amazon Prime, we were able to watch one right after the other, so we got totally spoiled!
summary: Amazon Prime:  Free Two Day Shipping and Downton Abbey...What?!!!! Fantastic!!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This has to be one of my favorite costume drama pieces ever to come out of England...and I guess I'm definitely not alone in that opinion.  I have watched them avidly on PBS and then went out and bought each DVD as they've come out and re-watched them again.  The intersecting stories of the nobility upstairs and the servants downstairs continues to intrique and enthrall.  I love to love some characters and I love to hate some characters, and some of them even switch in my affections over time.Season Three takes place in the early 1920's.  Now that WWI is behind Downton, the estate still isn't safe as they take a hit in their finances and have to come to terms with the idea of modernization.  Mary and Matthew are finally together (yeah!) and their wedding is beautifully done, but Matthew is clearly hopeful of a child (and heir) to be.  Edith loses out on her wedding dreams, but discovers her own voice.  I must say, I have gone from disliking her to liking her in this season.  The same with Ms O'Brien, as she becomes a deeper character who is sorry for her mistakes, but still has that sharp tongue.  While, Thomas...well, what can one say about Thomas.  He will emerge a bit of a dark hero by the end of this season.Not sure what I think about the new character of Rose, a young would-be flapper, but it looks like she will be joining the regular cast, and so far I'm liking her.  Also adored the brief bit with Shirley McLaine as Cora's mother and her sarcastic interaction with the Dowager (Maggie Smith)...what can be better with two fabulous actors like this!  Loved every moment of their conversational banter.The world is changing and Downton is changing with it, despite all the attempts of our favorite grumpy by the book yes M'Lord butler.  None of the characters stay static in this show and no one is safe from an untimely end, which makes the stories not only interesting but really sends you on an emotional rollercoaster.  Just when things look their best and brightest--watch out!Non-character stars of the show include the beautiful 1920's style clothing (bring back feathered and jeweled headbands!), the vintage cars, and Oh My! that wonderful trip to the Scottish Highlands that rounds out the season.  Perfect.  Just perfect.If you love Downtown, you will love this season...even if it will break your heart at times.  Can't wait until Season 4!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: There was no rating that says I love it and hate it at the same time so I guess I will have to write about it. The acting and the look of the show has not changed. Still great, and some great additional characters to add a little intrigue. What I hated, I really hated. However, it was the writers fault, not the actors. Rumors circulated that someone was going to die in season 3. I'll just say for the ones who haven't seen the show, I hate it when I am right. When the show was happy it was happy, and when the show was sad it was DEVASTATINGLY sad. A very emotionally draining season, that I am glad to an extent that I saw. I will not purchase it though until I see DA season 4. Lets just say that I think they have a lot to prove to me.
summary: This was hard to rate, so read my review.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I almost feel apart of this family! I feel sadness when they are sad and joy when they feel joy. The acting is phenomenal and I love every second of the show. I would recommend this show to anyone who appreciates great acting and historical pieces that seem to be happening right now. Great cast and every episode leaves a lasting impression. Hope it goes on for many seasons!!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Seasons 1 and 2 had me on the hook. I loved the story lines and the character developments.  The third season seemed like Fellows was trying too hard to trump the previous season rather than let the viewers delight in the interactions between the families and society.  The three weakest plot points tended to dominate the season and not for the series' betterment.  I still enjoyed seeing the characters I came to admire on the screen and now after the conclusion of Season 3, I know I will come back for more - even if just to see Mr. Carson help make sense of it all.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Though this has a soap opera feel to it at times, which I don't particularly care for, I really enjoy this show. It has the right amount of suspense to keep you hanging until the next episode, and I really enjoy this historical aspects, which are portrayed accurately. Overall one of my favorite shows.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The casting on this series is what makes it so successful.  It will be interesting to see ho the plot morphs through the timeline.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Impeccable. This TV series may be the best ever. Starting with the writing. Then the acting is wonderful. The music is too.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Undoubtedly one of the "first class" series to come along in the all too miserable lineup of dreadful and worthless shows we are forced to watch. Thank you for another extraordinarily entertaining season.  Keep them coming.  Also would like to say that the period costumes are absolute perfection as well as the set decor.

review_text: October 23 2013 Season 3 too:I heard about this tv series and decided to watch it. I fell in love with the characters, especially Matt and Mary, as well as Edith and one of the servants name Tom.  I was glued to my sit on every episode and watched it all in 2 days on demand of course. I believe they have a name for watching episodes in a marathon.  I love it that way!!!I can hardly wait for the next season as I have now caught up and watched everything they had done in all the prior seasons up to the horrible ending in the last season!! What a shocker. I will not divulge what it is so as not to spoil it but it is very surprising!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This is NOT my genre. I resisted watching this series despite constant begging from multiple family members and friends.  Having the week off around Christmas, I thought... what the heck.  I have Amazon Prime, so watching the series was free!Let me tell you... I watched TWO SEASONS IN THREE DAYS and I am suffering from major withdrawl today!  This series sort of treads water for the first two episodes but by number 3 it dives deep and remains there.  I was a terrible parent for the last three days while I hid myself in my bedroom with my kindle fire HD and watched this compulsively.  WOW.  LOVE IT.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: HII got the DVD last night and must say I was upset.I watched EPisode 5, having seen it on PBS Sunday night and there was a scene missing.  Running time was 49 minutes as opposed to PBS' 51 minutes.The scene missing was where Mrs Hughes in the kitchen mentions that there's a woman in the village who had a baby and can feed Sybil's baby.On the DVD  the only mention of the village woman is when Cora tells everyone in the drawing room upstairs.  I have noticed all PBS so far have run 51 minutes.  And the 2 version I watched on the DVD (UK version as sold by PBS)  runs 49.  I cant believe this. Why would they cut out 2- 2/12 minutes per eippisode on the DVD?Just wanted everyone to know.  But the quality is wonderful and none of that awful jumping which was evident in Season 2 dvd set which many people had a problem with including mine.
summary: Warning--DVd's are shorter than what shows on PBS. SCenes Missing

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Lots of interesting storylines this season. Some new additions, which are good. A few shocks, but I knew about them long before watching this season, so I was prepared. The antagonistic interaction between Violet and Isobel is always entertaining. Good to see Tom becoming a bigger part of the family. Many tricky issues resolved ethically during this season. It was gratifying to see Thomas' homosexuality eventually be accepted by everyone and especially Lord Grantham -- not sure what sentiments there were during the early 20s, but it was against the law. A common theme expressed by many of the characters was that he did not choose to be that way and there seemed to be genuine compasion for him.Overall, a great season with some shocking and sad events mixed with some very happy ones.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The show is wonderful and never a dull moment. Not afraid to make the story line twist and turn. I love it!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

review_text: I love this series. Very disappointed in the ending but am anxious to see what new things are to come.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: LOVE this series.  Wonderfully refreshing and a much needed alternative to all of the currently popular reality shows.  ENJOY all seasons!!!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: When I first began watching this series, I thought OMG, can't these people do anything for themselves? Then as I got more into it, I realized this is how the "class system works" and everyone knew their place.When the war began, and some of them got involved, I wanted to see how accurate their timelines were. I must say they were quite accurate. Seeing Mrs. Crawley start the hospital, at the Mansion, was great to see how the women were allowed to help in the war effort.I must say....I was dumfounded by the way season 3 ended. I believe I am still reeling from it.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I can't tell you why I loved it because I don't want to be a "spoiler" for those who haven't seen it yet.  But, dadgummit, why can't people just be allowed to be happy and live ever after, I ask?  If you don't want anymore hints, stop reading now....if you like to puzzle over veiled comments, keep reading:  after seeing the finale, I am boycotting season 4 until my sackcloth and ashes have been packed away once more.  Totally suck-egg way to end a season!!

review_text: I missed watching the series when it was originally on TV but I am thoroughly enjoying watching all the episodes from the beginning. The story is very well written.  It gives an inside look at British Nobility. The acting is superb.  It's hard to pick just one favorite character.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This season carries with it the untimely demise of two favorite characters-Lady Sybil and Matthew Crowley.And the jilting at the altar of Lady Sybil. But the best part was the much anticipated wedding of Mary and Matthew. Other highlights were the cricket match and the family's holiday trip to Scotland. There are many twists and turns in this season which makes it an attractive season (I liked the time when Cora's mother is visiting from the USA, and she is quite a contrast to her  English counterpart. ). Again , another splendid season which one could watch again and again.The three DVDs arrived on time and are of good quality. Surely, a great possession which I will cherish for a long time. In Downton Abbey the dialogues (especially of Maggie Smith)are worthh remembering and quoting!
summary: Tragic and exhilrating at the same time

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: We like the show a lot. But it's wearing on us a bit that every time they seem to struggle to think of what's next -- they kill-off a main character. Doing that 1 or 2 times for effect is 1 thing. Having it as a general plot dynamic that repeats indefinitely -- annoying. It's starting to be like they are trying to continuously get us attached and then pull our heart strings.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
reviewer_name: Grace Brunelle "Grace likes to spin fiber int...
review_text: Not only is downtown abbey visually pleasant, for those who like occasional twists and turns within multiple plot lines you will be very satisfied! Richly beautiful,the entire show pulls you into the story, giving both your heart and mind the shocks,joys and plotting on both up and downstairs. You will follow your favourite characters until something happens WTO either warm your il, and soul or jar it with surprises. The location is absolutely lush, the costumes are exquisite and historically correct. You will thoroughly enjoy it! I suggest you begin at season one ,so as to not become hopelessly lost. Enjoy reliving history within the setting of a true manor home from around1915 into the 1920's, and see both good, and bad choices,the changes in Enlish class culture. I really love this show, even with jolts and shocking cast losses, I go from pure relaxation to utter surprise due to excellent storyline writing and great acting! This is a great show!
summary: Anglophiles enjoy! A Must watch for adults!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I loved this season as much as I loved the first two.  Can hardly wait for season 4 on Prime

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Another great series from MPT. Some of the snobbery is hard to believe and makes me chuckle. Surely,  what is great about a Great House is that they "think "they are GREAT!  Loved that they family realizes they employ many people and are responsible for providing jobs, that's something anyway. I tried to imagine what role I would play if I lived during that time...probably one of the milk maids with revolutionary views. Generally, it is an excellent series even if it is hard to relate to the lifestyle on this side of the pond.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: My husband and I thoroughly enjoy glimpsing into the past society life in England. The interactions between the "titled" and the servants is quite intriguing. I'm loving the emerging female independence we're seeing in season 3.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I enjoy historical dramas set in dramatic buildings and grounds. I like to imagine how past customs, events, and technologies led to some of what I experience today; also fun to imagine that parts of human life are perennial as the grass regardless of all the rest of it--falling in love, having babies, relating across social classes and generations.  Downton Abbey delivers in those ways, yet falls into a bit of the 'soapy' realm in the screenplay. I watch, I enjoy and I look forward to Season 4 though Season 3 fell a bit short quality of the writing.
summary: Acting, set and costumes trump screenplay

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: There was a time,  back in the 1990's, when a BBC miniseries put as much emphasis on historical accuracy as it did on entertainment value, perhaps more.  I remember one such program set in the 1920's that was so slow moving and dull that drying paint would have been more interesting.  Those days are over, and Downton Abbey is not your father's BBC miniseries.  Historical accuracy is left for, well, to quote many speakers at the recent GOP convention,  the fact checkers to decide.  No, one does not see jet contrails over the manor house, or hear Led Zeppelin coming from a maid's room, but characters do utter words and phrases not yet coined.  In one episode, our dear Livinia is (in jest) said to be "sucking up to" her mother in law, which would have been a rather disturbing idea, between two adult women in 1919.In such a world, WWI showed up to add drama to the end of the last episode of the first season, and was gone, having taken out only a couple of superfluous characters, by the time we were 2/3 of the way through Season 2, all wounds healed, except on characters marked for dire ends in Season 3.  The Spanish Flu Pandemic (1919) arrived for one episode in Season 2, in order to take out another superfluous character, but just to make sure we understood her intentions, the episode introduced a Ouija board, so she could speak to us from the beyond.  Yep, this is the New BBC miniseries.  No child left behind.So, it was with no little excitement that Downton Abbey Season 3 crossed the atlantic early this year, and with Shirley MacLaine among the cast.Calm down, she only got three episodes, as the writers apparently didn't allow her a fortune big enough to save Downton Abbey, so there wasn't any need to keep her around once that was revealed.  This is not a spoiler.  Besides, it was a strangely subdued, almost sedated MacLaine.  I imagine she had to have shots due to wounds she suffered in the battle with her wardrobe.  For nearly all of her appearances, MacLaine, rather wildly dressed in 1920's gowns for mature women, seems to be getting swallowed whole by her costume, and can barely keep her head out of its throat, and as a result, is restricted to rather gnomic one liners intended to make her (a New York/Newport socialite) the paragon of Democracy, speaking Truth to the wily Old World landed gentry.As if...Anyone who's read Edith Wharton, or seen the movies ("House of Mirth") knows that American high society was as constricted, if not moreso, as any of the nobles of Europe, and just as class conscious.  MacLaine's character would have been fawning over the Granthams not pushing back.  AND she's Jewish?  You mean the titled families of England were marrying into foreign Jewish fortunes, in an era when anti-Semitism was barely disguised in the US, and some big wigs over there would later openly sympathize with Hitler?Again, cool down big feller, that's for them fact checkers...Yes, this is the topsy turvy world aimed at lightly educated Moderns, whose concepts of history are hazy at best, and who are so complacent in their world view, of the eternal character of the status quo, the Republic, that science is often thought of as merely "another opinion".  The New BBC Miniseries is a lot like its PBS cousins, education is but a minor component of its goal.Downton Abbey is pure entertainment in period clothes.  Too much thinking will only cause headaches and make enemies of those around you, who only want to be entertained.  It probably could be better, and who knows, more provocative, but would anybody watch it, these days?  It's sad to have to ask, but would they?
summary: The New! Improved! Tastier! (No Calories!) BBC Miniseries
