title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: If you haven't seen all of Season 3 and the 2012 Christmas special, called "A Journey to the Highlands", you probably don't want spoilers. I am going to give a synopsis of the Special Features, and that's difficult without giving some facts away as to season 3. Two important characters die in two different places on this 3-disc set (I won't say who, but the actor playing the one that dies during the Christmas Special wanted to leave the show). The deaths might make you want to take Julian Fellowes, writer and creator, to task. But then again, having tragedy amidst the joy is what makes "Downton Abbey" a really really great show. I have a couple people hooked on "Downton Abbey" who have never watched "Masterpiece Theater" before!This Season 3 DVD set contains three discs. It DOES have the 2012 Christmas Special. I have received my DVD set, ordered on this page, and it has parts 1 - 9 of Season 3, plus "A Journey to the Highlands" and 8 Special Features.DISC 1:Disc 1 has parts 1, 2, and 3 of Season 3 and 1 extra. English subtitles are available.Special Features:1. "Behind the Drama" (60 minutes) This is an fabulous overview of the first two seasons, with clips from the two seasons, interviews and rehearsal scenes. What I particularly liked is that it's not just a rehash of the plot lines, it includes why a plot line or character development was important or undertaken. Per the narrator, before WWI, there were 1.4 million people "in service" in England. Highclere Castle, "with more than 50 bedrooms, there was plenty to do." And plenty of rules, and the hierarchy below stairs was even stricter than above stairs.When a scene takes place upstairs, they are really filmed at Highclere Castle. When below stairs, though, they were filmed on sets at Ealing Studios. That's because though the magnificent upstairs is much the same (except for bathrooms!) now as it was before WWI, the kitchens and downstairs have been modernized.Remember the scene where "The Turk" enters Lady Mary's bedroom and she says, "You and my parents have something in common. You think I am much more of a rebel than I am." (Which is pretty humorous in itself, given that Mary is most tradition-hide-bound of the sisters.) Julian Fellowes tells us that the whole dead Turkish lover is based on a true story. A friend of his, who owns a Big House, "came upon a diary of one of his great-aunts, and this whole incident is recorded".The commentators also touch on the Spanish Flu epidemic, which may have killed up to 50,000,000 people world wide. Most flus are most lethal to the very young and the elderly. I've read that the Spanish Flu, however, was most lethal to healthy adults. It made your immune system go wild, attacking your body as well as the virus. So the healthier your immune system was, the more likely it was going to kill you.DISC 2:Disc 2 has parts 4. 5. 6. and 7 of Season 3. English subtitles are available. There are no special features on this disc.DISC 3:Disc 3 has parts 8 & 9 of Season 3, as well as "A Journey to the Highlands" (the 2012 Christmas special) and 7 Special Features. English subtitles are available.Special Features:1. "Downton in 1920" (20 minutes) Commentators include Julian Fellowes (writer and creator), Brian Percival (director, episodes 1 & 2), Magi Vaughan (make up & hair designer), Caroline McCall (costume designer), Charmain Adams (production designer), Elizabeth McGovern (plays Cora, Countess of Grantham), Michelle Dockery (plays Lady Mary), Laura Carmichael (plays Lady Edith), Alastair Bruce (historical advisor), Jim Carter (plays Mr. Carson the butler), Lesley Nichol (plays Mrs. Patmore, the cook), Jessica Brown Finlay (plays Lady Sybil), Sophie McShera (plays Daisy Mason, cook assistant), Allen Leech (plays Tom Branson, the chauffeur), Brendan Coyle (plays John Bates), Gareth Neame (executive producer), Shirley MacLaine (plays Martha Levinson, Cora's American mother), Dan Stevens (plays Matthew Crawley), and Pete Gaine (from Motorhouse Hire Ltd, who supplied Matthew's marvelous 1920 car).In Season 3, it's 1920. When we think 1920, we think "The Roaring Twenties". But, as Caroline McCall points out, "I think people's perception of the 20's is very different from 1920."  Julian Fellowes points out that the Charleston dance craze didn't happen until 1926. The hair and costume designers had to show fashions changing gradually, because it's not as if everyone started dressing like flappers in 1920.The rigid laced-up corsets of before the war, give way to bandeau corsets and breast-flattening bras. Even the men show subtle changes in their suit jackets, etc. Except for Mr. Carson, of course, who continues to wear exactly the same suit he always has.It wasn't just clothing that was changing. As Alastair Bruce says, "We see this great imperial family gradually alter, as moral conscience takes us on a different path." Very much the way the Imperial British Empire was altering.2. "The Wedding of Lady Mary" (18 minutes) Commentators include many from extra #1, with new ones: Victoria Brooks (head of publicity for "Downton Abbey"), Liz Turbridge (producer), Matthew 'Sparky' Ellis (location manager), Charmain Adams (production designer), Maggie Harris (resident of Bampton, where the wedding was filmed), Rev. David Lloyd (Vicar of Bampton), Timothy Word (crowd assistant director), Danielle Bennett (second assistant director), Rupert Steggle (crowd costume assistant), Hugh Bonneville (plays Robert, Lord Grantham), Rob James-Collier (plays Thomas Barrow, footman and troublemaker), Chris Croucher (first assistant director), Stephen Sorby (from Above the Line Security) and Joanne Froggatt (plays Anna Bates).Victoria Brooks says, "It's almost the next royal wedding, dare we say it!" There were 209 total crew & cast, including the extras, and the paparazzi was wild to get a photo of "Mary" in her wedding dress.3. "The Wedding of Lady Edith" (25 minutes) Commentators include many who also appear in the first 2 extras, as well as Robert Bathurst (plays Sir Anthony Strallan), Denis Maguire (supporting artist, plays the photographer at the church), David Holt (special effects technician) and Damian Butlin (standby propman).Poor Edith - how many of us think that? Julian Fellowes says, "Her self-rebuilding will become another part of the story.... The subliminal message, I think, is we must get behind the wheels of our own lives."We should take a poll. Did Sir Anthony act out of misguided honor or is he just a jerk? And if we don't think he's a jerk, how about Lord Robert's part in this?4. "The Men of Downton Abbey" (12 minutes) Commentators appear in the first 3 specials. This focuses on how WWI was the changemaker, whether you were above stairs or below stairs. Hugh Bonneville says, "After the turmoil of the war, Robert thinks, in a way, that life will return to the way it was before the way. And, of course, it never will."Alastair Bruce adds, "People have survived something [in WWI], and they are never going to forget what they've gone through.... It changes their view of what they expect from the world."5. "Shirley MacLaine at Downton" (16 minutes) MacLaine hadn't been watching "Downton Abbey" herself, but she had friends who were addicts. It's a sign of how good the show is that it could get a Shirley MacLaine to be in it. Sophie McShera groans, "I didn't get to meet Shirley MacLaine and I'm so jealous."Rob James-Collier is excited just talking about the meeting of Shirley Maclaine and Dame Maggie Smith on the show. "They are going to be epic, they really are. Two actual legends on screen, battling it out. The only thing I can liken it to is DeNiro vs Pacino in "Heat"!" ("Heat" is an American 1995 movie.)6. "Behind the Scenes: The Cricket Match" (10 minutes) Many commentators appear before. New ones are Eddie Williams (3rd assistant director), Adam Ghillam (camera operator), Kevin Doyle (plays Molesley, the butler for Mrs. Crawley, Matthew's mother), Ed Speleers (plays Jimmy Kent, new footman), Cora Theobold (plays Ivy Stuart, new kitchen maid), David Evans (director episodes 7 & 8) and Matt Milne (plays Alfred Nugent, footman).The match took three days to shoot. Mr. Carson takes part, and Jim Carter says, "It's lovely for Carson to be out in his cricket gear. First time in three years I've had a change of clothes." Only one cast member taking part in the match actually knew how to play cricket. Thanks to stand-ins and clever camera work, you wouldn't know it.7. "Behind the Scenes: A Journey to the Highlands" Many familiar commentators, with these new ones: Lily James (plays Lady Rose MacClare), Andy Goddard (director for this episode) and Diana Scrivener (choreographer). For this 2012 Christmas special, cast and crew traveled, for filming, to Inveraray Castle, Scotland, seat of the real Duke of Argyll. Incredibly beautiful scenery, but everybody complains about the outdoor scenes where they were attacked by hordes of midges.For the show, Inveraray stands in for Duneagle Castle, home of Sir Robert's cousin, Hugh 'Shrimpy' MacClare. His 18 year-old daughter, Rose, will, according to Julian Fellowes become a prominent character going forward. The staff that stays home at Downton Abbey aren't forgotten, and the episode shifts back and forth between Scotland and Downton. New romance is in the air for more than one character. Lesley Nichol says she asked Fellowes to give Mrs. Patmore a love interest, and he complied. Lesley says, "Mr. Tufton has taken over our local shop. He's a bit of a flirty ponce, which shocks her [Mrs. Patmore] sideways, really, because I don't think people flirt with Mrs. Patmore."Season 4 of "Downton Abbey" starts filming in late February 2013. I can't wait to see it!
summary: DOES have 2012 Christmas Special, NINE Episodes, Here's a Synopsis of DVD Special Features!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The characters and story are believable.  Perhaps the best of all is that the characters are real and l can identify with each one (sometimes painfully) in one way or another.  When we have watched one episode we can hardly wait for the next one because the actors/actresses draw us into their lives.  I especially appreciate the underlying moral tone of the series which stands out in contrast to other 'stuff' on TV.  There is some violence and sex, but they fit the story and lives of the characters without being overdone.  We also like the smooth flow of the episodes and of the series as a whole, because it is historically based and takes us along on its journey with the characters and situations.  This is a great series, and perhaps the best we have ever watched.  Keep up the good work and keep Downton Abbey coming.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: has come and gone.  We have been Brit TV fans for 30 years and counting.  We've primarily followed the various mystery series but have also enjoyed other offerings.  Downton Abbey has taken their TV productions to new heights in a way that Julian Fellows probably never thought possible, but at the same time a sense of detachment and disappointment has settled in after this season.  l hate to be spiteful but it's slowly evolving into an extremely well produced soap opera.  With the various characters coming and going you get the sense they're trying to keep the storyline alive but too many improbable events add up to hard-to-believe episodes.  This entire series has been the best of the best and I consider it to be the crowning achievement of Brit TV. Some of us, a lot of us, here in America have a serious appetite for this formal English society with all its maneuvering and back biting - regardless of our social emphasis on the everyman here.  It's a look back at a different culture, done in an amazingly detailed manner, in an incredibly gorgeous setting, with acting as only the British can bring to the screen.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Worth every cent in price, every minute in time. A powerful period costume drama (some call a Soap) with historical excellence upstaged by perfection in acting. It's the "Roots" of historical family drama for the 21st century. You'll drool your champagne over locations, costumes, props, and sets.AND IT'S TO CONTINUE FOR A 4th SEASON. The biggest question is not will it maintain the UK and US growing following, but will it contain Matthew Crowley (Dan Stevens). But he's at least back doing his best and wedding Mary (Michelle Dockery) and will take over the realm of Downton Abbey, even though Earl Robert (Hugh Bonneville) has bungled the finances, always a plot among the early English wealthy families.Yes, much of the former cast is back, joined with the American upstart actress Shirley MacLaine playing Cora's (Elizabeth McGovern) American mother. With this huge star going against the impeccable delivery of lines from Dowager Violet (Maggie Smith), the excitement and cast excellence remains. Combined, these 2 drive a thread of sharp-spark delight through this third series. She's welcomed by cast and viewers. Past issues, like imprisonment, the Bates, Anna & John, also continues in romance/tragedy form.Although the UK gets first peeks, it is America that is driving worldwide success. It will continue in some form, and at the peak of seductive drama.To Downton Abbey fans, it is just "family" being viewed.The 1920 English lifestyle of the aristocrat and their home staff has never been presented better since Upstairs, Downstairs. Only time will tell if Downton Abbey fans will drive this series beyond the regal success of U,D. I suspect they will. It's powerful writing coming from the pen of Julian Fellowes, and perhaps will end only at his decision. The writing behind the Abbey is as deliciously alluring toward characters as Catherine Cookson's work. Already the public demands more, I and my wife included. She nearly wore out season 2 DVDs and will do likewise to Season 3. We'll order Season 4 as soon as the listing appears.SUBTITLED.Not a rental. It's a MUST OWN. Place it on the all-time classic shelf.Do you own season's 1&2?Downton Abbey Seasons 1 & 2 Limited Edition Set - Original UK Version
summary: A TV CLASSIC in the making, 6-STAR WORTHY

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey is why the Brits excell in story telling.  Somewhere deep within, they cling to the whole Haves & have-not issue which has existed in Britain for hundreds of years.  The idea that servants somehow deserve more, but probably wouldn't take it if they could, fuses the whole " pressure makes diamonds" cliche.  Upstairs Downstairs, but with a shorter set of stairs; that's Downton Abbey.  As for Americas fascination with this amazingly well produced soap opera harkens back to Washingtons troops laying eyes for the first time on actual Red Coats, prior to moving forward into Revolutionary War battles.  " Are these guys actually gonna fight in that regalia?"  We love the unique intrigue, tho a similar drama based on pre-Civil War intrigues featuring wealthy white slave owners would never work here!
summary: Downton Abbey Places The Little Guy Above The Frey In Downton Abbey

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Series 3 was a huge disappointment to me for several reasons.  The stories did not flow as nicely as Series 1 and 2.  For instance, the storyline about Matthew's indecision about taking Reggie Swire's fortune was a total waste of time.  It added nothing to the series and it only served to show Mary's ugly side.  I also didn't understand why some of the characters' personalities changed.  For instance, Lord Grantham suddenly became an incompetent loser who couldn't seem to hold things together. Then we have two new footmen and Cousin Rose who were awful additions.  All of the stories involving the two footmen and Rose seemed to be written in a hurry and thrown in willy nilly and again did not add anything to the continuing saga of Downton Abbey.  And for all the hype about Shirley Maclaine being added to the cast and her interaction with Maggie Smith's character, that was a total bust.  Shirley Maclaine's acting was awful and her role was so small that she could have phoned it in.  The so-called "brilliant" exchanges with Maggie Smith never materialized.  And what happened to Cora?  They should have killed off her character when she had the Spanish flu because all she does is walk through the scenes with that silly smile and her head lowered.  The only time she showed any emotion was when Lady Sybil died.  Other than that she does nothing useful and surprisingly shows very little interest in Sybil's baby.  Not once did she hold the baby.  Branson is another character who underwent a huge personality change.  He became a robot.  He needs to ride off into the sunset with his daughter.  The deaths of two main characters did not bother me so much as the poor script.  It appears to me that Fellowes has gotten bored with Downton or maybe his mind has been too much on the American program he is making.  As I understand it, other writers will be making the future scripts and that's usually not a good thing.  I enjoyed the first two series of Downton Abbey immensely, but Series 3 has turned me off so much that I don't think I will be watching it in the future.

review_text: Not much to really add here. Downton Abbey is arguably one of the best period series to hit the airwaves; here in the U.S. and across the pond. From the stunning Cybil to the ever conforming Mr. Carson to the do-gooder Matthew. Their all here at their best! And while the season(series?) finale episode will leave you trying to make sense of it all, I strongly suggest you watch this awesome story from the very first episode in season 1. Entertainment at it's best and the picture quality through Amazon Prime streaming is excellent. Spend some quality time with the Crawleys. You won't be sorry.

review_text: The series is probably one of the most complete in television history. One watches to see how the characters lives unfold. title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: There are some fine moments -- Thomas and James sorting it out near the end for instance; the beauty of the Scottish landscape, etc. but the writer finds no way to develop the relationship between Matthew and Mary other than to have them off each other or sentimentally enrapt with little in the way of nuances.  This lack of development reflects a lack of imagination or interest in complex human interaction.  Since the first two seasons were primarily driven by the chemistry between these two characters and the possibilities of bringing them together, this two dimensional and clumsy handling of their marriage has the effect of letting all the air out of the balloon.  Instead, we get a shifting of focus from one relationship or situation to another to keep us interested.  It works for a time but sooner or later the audience wants to be fed and most of what transpires is not satisfying.  Killing off characters is dramatic as death has a way of stealing a scene or two, but good drama it is not.

The Irish guy is the only sensible character out of them all. How such trivial things occupy their minds when you don't have to worry about paying the rent or shopping for food on a small budget. Still like the show, just can't figure out why.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Over the past year I had heard all the great excitement about this series from many friends with different tastes, and couldn't understand what the difference could be between DA and Upstairs, Downstairs. I mean, really, hasn't the British empire saga been pushed down the throats of every English-speaking country via film, etc. for decades? Aren't we over it? But curiosity led me to stream the very first episode, then the next, and a few weeks later, here I am nearly caught up and ready to watch on a Sunday night with the rest of the fans. I especially love the Irish character named Thomas Branson. As the American wife of a man from Belfast, Northern Ireland and therefore someone who has been around Brits for over 30 years, I am amazed at how well Branson expresses the Irish Republican opinions of that time (when Eamon DeValera and Michael Collins were leading the struggle for freedom), and the Crawleys' various reactions to him. Well done, the whole lot!
summary: Now I know what all the (fabulous) fuss is about

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey has all the elements that I love: history, drama, romance, humor and a touch of evil here and there just to add to the flavor. It illustrates the changes brought about technological advances and the impact of World War I on British lives.  Old ways of living had to give way to new, albeit reluctantly by some and joyfully embraced by others. However, the best part of Downton Abbey is that women rule it, although they do it with such subtle finesse that the men don't even realize how outmatched they are. The nuances of human behavior are captured with witty dialogue and contrasting scenes between the upper class and those that serve them, all the while showing us what silly creatures we humans can be.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The whole family is geared up waiting for season 3.  We even rewatch Season 1 & 2 in anticipation.  The actors and actresses are so good.....the characters they play are so interesting.  We watched 'modern' vs 'tradition' and love love love Maggie's role as the matriarch of the family.....And then what happens.....oh yeah...if something good happens, something very evil must happen; and not just once but twice...and what's left ?...No details.  I don't want to give it away but then I should so others don't watch it....my son and his wife were so totally bummed that they are not ever going to watch it again.  My husband and I then proceeded and I had to take some time off because of grief #1 and then the 'finale'.....did the writers forget that we love these characters and without them...the show just isn't the same.  Also, is there no imagination left to continue a story...if that's what happened then Season 2 should have been the end.  We are all disgusted with Season 3 and the lack of imagination and the removal of the 'heart' of the story.  If the writers would ask me, I would tell them that it isn't tragedy that makes a good show...it is the characters...we are interested in the characters and all the actors and actresses were playing their parts excellently.  They make the story.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: DOWNTON ABBEY,  Season 1, 2, 3The story has captivated my attention from the first time I saw Season1 on PBS So Cal. Absolutely perfect the way each character is blended with the other. One gets so intrenched with with each story line — it takes you out of this world of multi-problems and you become a part of the entire cast.  "YOU ARE THERE"  Although I own all the DVD's of all three seasons, I still go back a review ALL of them again.  Each time I catch a line that had been missed, or a scene the had been over looked.  I still watch each program on PBS So Cal each Sunday, although I know what will happen.  Waited impatiently for each season to be released,  The photography is out of this world, the outdoors, and especially the location.  Really enjoyed every minute to date.However, the story can end here. !!!Loosing interest because you have eliminated two (2) of the main family characters. [Sybil Crawley & Matthew Crawley —Strange]I have lost  interest in the new an younger people that are being introduced. Too much like TV America petty situation comedy (2013)  Ergo, I think you have/are turning a wonderful 'Classic Story' into a 'Modern Day Soap-Opera'... and we all know they are no longer on television. (personal belief)  I think that Julian Fellowes should have stopped after 'Mary Crawley' had her child... "Grandson & Heir to Downton." Would have been a wonderful 'Cliff-Hanger'Now the story line/s have become disengaged— Also, Shirley MacLaine did an expected job of playing "Shirley MacLaine" !!!  (The last of the Rat Pack).  Outside of her, every star in 'Downton Abbey' deserves an Academy Award, non of course could top... Dame Maggie Smith.  Accolades to the Cast, Directors, Producers and writers.  Excellent job, enjoyed every minute... viewed over and over!Too bad this is the end for me,  IT Has now lost the magic... and becoming Standard America ; 'Situation Tragedy'.Respectfully,James-Alan Love[First generation American, my parents-grandparents are from England]

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I watched and mostly enjoyed the first two seasons, and the intrigue of seeing early 20th century British culture in HD was enough to pull me through some of the painfully formulaic moments and annoying acting tics (like Cora's accent). But the period novelty starts to wear off by the middle of Season 3, as does any sense that there's an overarching plan to the writing--or at least enough to outweigh the show's business interests. Instead, the plot twists are clearly designed to keep actors they need and get rid of actors (not characters) they can't keep, and it's all too transparent to suspend disbelief anymore or to emotionally invest in the storyline (and if you can't do that, what's the point of watching?). On the bright side, having a show fall off like this gives it a form of closure, and I come out happy for the brief escape but with zero gumption to re-up my interest for Season 4.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey is so well produced that one can't help but like it.  I am not sure how accurate the interaction between the "upstairs" and "downstairs" is, but one gets some idea of how life of the English nobility played out.  The costumes are extraordinary, especially the dresses worn by the ladies.  The acting, in my opinion, is superb.  We find it enjoyable and interesting.
summary: Downton Abby- a peak into the life of English nobility.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Each season adds more drama and intrigue. Well written and the new actors always add. Shirley Maclaine was excellent!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: But I do enjoy the characters that are presented by premium venerable actors (both male and female.) It could be considered an old world soap opera but it is presented as so much more if you follow it from season 1. Things haven't changed much from the turn of the century to present day as far as people of notoriety and power are concerned. The underlying human emotions that exist at Downton Abbey is well worth the time to experience and reflect upon.

review_text: The acting is tremendous, the story line compelling, the sets and costumes fabulous. The time in history is rarely written about and it is exciting to see the changes in class structure that take place due to the war and the ensuing economic challenges.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: If you’re my age, it’s pretty much a remake of Upstairs, Downstairs and if it didn’t have Maggie Smith, I don’t think I’d watch it at all. It’s full of stereotypes and pretends that people like the aristocratic family were ever so kind to their servants, rather than seeing them as inferior beings--a bit like the supposed kindly slave owner.Having said all that, I do enjoy these period pieces and this one is as good as any in the sense that the Brits do these very well--and there’s Maggie Smith, of course!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: ***POSSIBLE SPOILERS***I have been a fan of Downton Abbey since the first episode transported me to another time and place.  I have watched with awe the brilliant attention to detail and wonderful actor/actresses and writing propel this show to be a continued hit not only in England but around the world.  I can't wait for Series 4.  Sure,  some things in 3 made me sad....I really wish the actor and actress who chose a different path would have stayed on at Downton, I for the life of me can't fathom why you would leave such a popular show that is such an international hit but to each his or her own.  I think it was handled as well as could be given the circumstances...I would certainly rather have Matthew die than him and Mary "separate" due to not getting along or some such nonsense and "easy out".  Either way, I think anyone with any taste for quality dramatic series would not just enjoy this series, they will adore it!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I never use to care much for "period pieces," but my daughters told me that I'd love it, and they were right.  I found every aspect of this show of the highest quality, and it has pulled me in from the very first season episode.  I absolutely LOVE the actors, the characters, the  writing, the story, the scenes, the props, the beauty of the homes, as well as the landscape, not to mention the beautiful accents.  I've never had the desire to travel outside of the USA, with the possible exception of the UK, as my ancestors are all an American mix of Scottish, Welsh, Irish, and English, but I now find myself wanting to book a trip to the UK as something on my bucket list!  Each season gets better!  I can't wait until January 2014 for the 4th season!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: More loose ends tied, more new subplots revealed.  Robert is the penultimate Victorian nobleman being dragged, kicking and screaming into the 20th century, while the world and his family discover their own frailties and humanity.  Downton Abbey moves on with the help of its dissidents, Tom, the former chauffeur and Matthew, the son-in-law.I was saddened by the loss of Matthew, as I thought he held the future of Downton Abbey is his hands.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This series started out brilliantly, but then seems to have had a succession of mini-jump-the-shark moments that want to make you roll your eyes.  There are also so many scenes where otherwise worldly, intelligent, extremely astute characters must become utterly clueless and dumb about the goings-on about them, in order for the plot intrigue to develop.  These devices have now been used so frequently throughout the series that they've become predictable, and tiresome.  I'll probably watch the series to the bitter end, because it's fun in a cheesy way, but Masterpiece Theater it isn't.
summary: Plot line is on a constant downhill slide

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Acting in this is good the story line is what sets this apart from the contemporary television of today. This show gives you a look from a historical perspective and is quite accurate. The main part of the story that intrigued me the most though is the alternate perspectives of the service class and the aristocracy they work for. It brings forth the challenges faced by both sides of this coin and the perspectives of both in a heart warming and entertaining way.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: With gorgeous period sets, a wide range of characters, a lot of feel good moments and a few very sad circumstances, season three of Downton Abbey is still one of the most enjoyable shows on television. When the season opens it's 1920, and the ladies of the house are all wearing updated fashions, Mary and Matthew are finally getting married, Edith is hoping for a romance of her own, Sybil is pregnant and may not make it home from Ireland for the wedding, Mr. Bates is still serving time in prison, and Thomas and O'Brien are no longer plotting evil together--they're now enemies.This DVD divides the show into more segments than the PBS version did, which makes it a little confusing if you're trying to follow American blog postings about each episode, but everything is here, including the Christmas special--so named because it was shown on Christmas day in Britain but isn't set during the Christmas season. Instead of a Yuletide celebration show, the family is off to Scotland, a special treat for people like me who are also fans of Monarch of the Glen.
summary: Another great season--with the Christmas special included

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Season three was awesome. Not as awesome as season two, but still. I like how Downton Abbey doesn't "jump the shark", in that when TV shows gets so self-aware of how much people like it they tend to start to sell the characters out. The characters still struggle. They still have real-life situations that turn their world upside down. I like that you can always count on the characters to be real and you can count on the writing to be honest.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: We love Downton Abbey, in fact we bought this episode because it was described as "the original British version".  But instead of extra scenes, scenes were missing.  We also thought it would be Episode 3, (so far we had watched 1 & 2), and it was a repeat of Episode 2.  AND we had friends over for the "big event"'.  So there is definite confusion in the description of this show.  Amazon made it right, and support was very swift and excellent in helping me recover my password,  I've mentioned that to everyone I know,  no complaints there.  But we won't be buying any more episodes.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Splendid!  Enjoyed getting to know the Crawleys and the interworkings of Mary and Matthew; Isobel and Violet; Robert and Cora and the list goes on.  How nice to have a series that actually focuses on people and their relationships rather than sex and violence.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: It depicts a life style we could barely imagine with traditions we have never encountered and values we have lost. I was caught by surprise by the beauty of the area and a lavish way of life taking place in a far simpler time frame yet not devoid of turmoil.No, the sequence of events did not always please me as obviously it did some reviewers but such is life.If there is need to escape reality for a while and to embark on a fascinating journey, then, Downton Abbey is the key to that door.The acting is superb, the local astounding, the timeline followed in the most minute detail.Anyone with the slightest touch of imagination remaining will get absorbed in this saga. However, if CGI is required, bare skin needed and foul language a must, then this is not for you.
summary: A slice of life from another loaf.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This series is superb quality in every way.....production, writing, acting.  If you allow eyes to wander, the set design, house and grounds itself are a visual feast.  It is a wonderful way to learn about a period in time when all things changed. The grand homes of Lords and Ladies are about to become more socially and economically responsive. Despite their titiles and wealth, they are no longer insulated from the common man.  It's a fascinating period of change.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This show is so well written and the acting is outstanding.  I absolutely love it. The photography is beautiful as well. The characters are realistic and likeable. It is wonderful to be able to follow the lives of the Crawley family through another season. The U.K. version is so much better than the PBS version, so I recommend avoiding the PBS version. It is difficult to follow. This is now my favorite show!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I have given 5 stars to every season however I had to take away one star this season. At the end of the season I begin to see character "slips" that didn't quite fit the character.Robert is a great example. From the very beginning he is shown to be a person that always wants to do right as well as be honest and upstanding (sort of an example for the village). In the next to the last episode (the cricket match) he coerces his employees to say and do what he wants,even as his employee tells him that his conscience tells him that he should do what he did. Robert goes against that, and on top of it  makes the employee say that he might have had too much to drink, even though that's not true.I'll be honest, I've already read the reviews for Season 4 because I'm about to start it. I have to agree with some of the reviewers that some of these characters have taken a total opposite turn. I also am aware that this time period did have a lot of change as far as way of life but aren't we from the very first be led to see the Granthams and Crawleys as respectable employers of the village? That they are kind people with money that will do anything to help their employees, even to the point of helping  them obtain other jobs away from the Abbey if it makes the employee happy? I don't think I would think of my employer respectable if I were made to say things that weren't true, as well as implied that I was drinking.Perhaps as one review said, Julian Fellowes has seemed to run out of ideas. Here's one: instead of destroying characters that we love, how about go back to the beginning and show the story of Robert and Cora and him bringing a young American girl to England to live and the struggles she faced when she was young adapting to their way of life? Who knows, it might open the door for better story lines and characters that stay within their character. I start Season 4 with almost apprehension rather than excitement. We'll see what happens!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: For those of you who like masterpiece theatre or any shows that are from different historical eras then you will like this one.  This takes place at a time when the industrial age was changing things really fast.  Class is not as apparent as it once was and the lower working class is not necessarily staying in its place.  I love this series because it shows us the incredible changes these people went through particularly with regard to the social changes from servant class to upper class/ruling class. It explores the changes in women's roles as well.  The acting is amazing.  Love this show!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: So rarely does anyone like what I like. One might say I have bad taste. I prefer to think of it as broad taste. You can imagine my surprise when I learned that I love the most critically acclaimed show on TV. What's more, it reminds me so much of one of my favorite movies -  Gosford Park (which you should watch if you haven't seen it). A peak into the world of the rich and their servants in the early 20th century sounds boring, but the sharp-as-knives wit and humor make it so much more relatable.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I usually avoid soap operas, but this show has an unusual and interesting background and setting.  I find the characters varied and interesting.  The social aspects of the times and the wealthy are also interesting.I avoided this show as it played out, but by starting at the beginning episode and following through for nearly three seasons so far has made it much more interesting to me.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I love, love, love Downton Abbey!  With all the reality shows, of which I'm not a fan, and violence in many of the shows on primetime, Downton Abbey takes us back to a time when things seemed much simpler.  Family was most important, they actually sit and talk with each other and they aren't distracted by all the gadgets and electronics that seem so prevalent today.  I love the separateness of the servants and the owners of the home and how the relationships intertwine.  Most of them have such respect for one another, but there are a few conniving characters that make it even more fun to watch.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The major conflicts that threatened Downton Abbey in Season 1 and Season 2 have fully been resolved.  The heir apparent Matthew Crawley has wedded his cousin Mary, and the Crawley clan is more than ever ensconced in their way of life.  World War I and the ravages of Influenza are over, and Downton Abbey has returned to its normal and happy state of not giving a rat's fart about the rest of the world.  So it's imperative that the show invents/fabricates new tensions and conflicts to keep the slow inexorable train that is the Downton Abbey plotline moving.The major conflict in Season 3 is tradition vs. modernity, the go-to conflict in period dramas when it's clear audiences have little patience for real issues and problems.  The heir and de facto owner of Downton Abbey Matthew Crawley is intent on importing modern business and farming practices to make Downton Abbey self-sustainable, whereas the patriarch Robert Crawley is upset that his tenants may thrown at the mercy of the market.  But apparently Matthew is not at all happy with the Crawley tradition of financially ruining the estate and therefore forced to happily pursue beautiful American heiresses.  Robert then responds that wise investments can save good tranditions -- isn't Ponzi a good investment?The appeal of Downton Abbey is not in its writing (which is lazy and self-indulgent) or in its acting (Elizabeth McGovern is apparently only capable of an expression that's half-chagrin and half-smile -- stop taking that Botox, Elizabeth!).  It's that the people of Downton Abbey are immensely likable, and its self-contained world and all its petty politics and problems a happy relief and escape from our own messy modernity.
summary: The March of Cliches and Caracatures Continues

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I received the DVDs last week and I'm certainly enjoying them.  However, I have one BIG complaint.  I have noticed that at least a few scenes that aired on PBS are not on the DVDs.  (As of today's date, PBS has not even finished airing Season 3, so who knows how many more scenes I'll discover are missing.)I have watched the previous two seasons on PBS and then purchased the DVDs.  The DVDs for Seasons 1 and 2 feature additional scenes that were not aired on PBS.  We know that at least for the first two seasons, PBS edited the program to fit their time slot, and it was understood that the "Original UK Versions" of the DVDs contained scenes that PBS had cut.  When my Season 3 DVDs arrived, I was looking forward to seeing all the "extras" that had not aired on PBS. It has been very disappointing to not only not find the extras I was hoping for, but to see that scenes and portions of scenes I saw on PBS are missing.  (I have the two "official" books on Downton and have read various interviews with the actors, etc.  Based on what I have read in these sources, scenes appear to have been cut even before it aired in the U.K., and the actors and author of the books were seemingly not aware of this.  How disappointing!)In my opinion, it is misleading for PBS to advertise it as the "Original UK Edition."  Although this statement may technically be true, based on their experience with the past two seasons, fans of the show have understood this to mean they are getting a more complete version of the season.  It would be great if they would release versions for all three seasons that include EVERYTHING before the final edits were made for British or American TV.
summary: Love it, but disappointed about missing scenes

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: My wife and I became hooked on Downton Abby after watching the first two seasons. It is simply one of the best series on TV today.  The upcoming wedding of Matthew and Mary is taking center stage as the season starts.  This season is so dramatic and the storyline so involved that I do not want to spoil any of it for you.  Let's just say that there are several shockers in this season and it will leave you wanting more.Action, tragedy, love and tragedy make this season so involved.  It is not like you are watching a movie or TV series because the characters are so real that you feel that you are living the storyline with them.  This feeling is brought across the screen and into your home because of the excellent cast and the perfect script that just keeps you hanging onto every event.This is television drama at its best and it is so good that it is addicting.  My wife and I think it is the best show on TV and we love watching it.  We rated it a 5 star series and recommend it to you.  It makes me wonder why American TV cannot make shows like this anymore.
summary: The best drama series on TV!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I like seeing times past and wish we had more of some of those things in our lives today. The respect and art of being a gentleman and a lady -- having gotten lost over time I think, is neat to see it in Downton Abbey.  We breezed through all three seasons after having heard about them here and there.  Wish we hadn't breezed through them though.  I wonder if we'll watch Season 3 again before Season 4.  There is a Season 4, isn't there? And, no, I didn't like the ending and what I've heard that means.  Too bad.  :(

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I started watching Downton Abbey a month ago and with the fantastic media streaming I was able to watch Seasons 1 - 3. title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: A person doesn't watch this series for Action Adventure or situational humor. Maybe it is the lack thereof in this series that makes it such a standout now on American TV. I love this quiet drama. I love the use of language, the nuanced exploration of class and station, and of course, the attention paid to the sets and costumes. Season three begins with a resolved conflict between two of the main characters that went on for the first two seasons, so it feels like major new plot threads are starting and I can't wait to see where the writers take the story. BTW the writer for DA, Julian Fellowes, is the same forGosford Park, so if you liked that movie and other period pieces of early 19th century, you will probably love DA as I do.BTW I watched the first two seasons for free with Amazon Prime with myRoku HD Streaming Player. That was so much easier than having to wait for Netflix to send the disks.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I just love hearing Violet (the Dowager Countess of Grantham) make her remarks to her family.  She pulls no punches, takes no prisoners.  She says exactly what she thinks, but so creatively, you have to listen closely to catch the sarcasm.  Her well-placed remarks are a theme that winds through the entire series.  She copes better with change than her son Robert, and supports her granddaughters as they embark upon some modern ventures.  While she struggles with maintaining a certain standard of living with the concomitant price for the high style, she is sensitive to the notion of noblesse oblige, and works hard to be supportive of the entire county.  As she matches wits with Isobel Crawley,and says some unkind things like "doesn't that halo get heavy?, she also reveals just how much she cares for the servants and farmers employed by Downton Abbey. I can't stop watching to see what she will say next.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Friends from Texas introduced us to this program in June by having us watch the first episode from Season 1.  We were so impressed that we watched all three seasons practically non-stop.  Each episode had been so spell-binding that we were sorry there were not enough hours in the day to watch the next episodes.  The historical account of the early 20th century aristocracy along with the servitude of the maids and footmen and the interactions among them was dealt with accuracy and added to the various plots found with these series.  We are definitely hooked and we can't wait for season 4 to start up.

review_text: Season 3 of Downton Abbey is very good, but not great like seasons 1 & 2. The cliffhanger aspect works to keep interest piqued for the next round.The interjection of modern social issues was a bit ham-handed, leading some characters to behave in ways that seemed contrary to their established personae.Overall, though, good show.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I got into the series after season 3 aired and viewed all 3 seasons over 6 months.  I am a big reader and often my books cover historical time periods.  I have enjoyed seeing some of the period's subtle issues come to life…the need for an heir, the affects of the War on a changing society in all classes, women's more independent role, etc.  And I think that he(?) has done a very good job of acclimating the stories to TV given the challenges of characters who do not come back after contracts are done…. While nothing beats a good book where you can fill in the details with your imagination and an author doesn't have to write off a character because the character is done, Downton Abbey does a great job telling it's story.
summary: Enjoy the series; brings a time period to life

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I'm not a fan of "reality TV" and am delighted to see that there is something worth watching.  This is an intelligent show with a historical setting.  It gives insight into a time when the class structure in British society was so important and when women had few rights.  As in "Upstairs Downstairs", the viewer sees life among the aristocracy and the working class and how it evolved.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I love this show for the quality of the characters, the setting, and the historical background it shares.  The drama and tension and love between the characters offers the viewer some nail-biting moments as well as funny moments.  The show truly shows compassion for fellow humans and encourages viewers to take the high road in our own lives.  It is not all polly-Anna-ish for sure.  Displaying the classist thoughts of the era is eye-opening and outright disturbing but no surprise.  Overall love most characters and the great costuming and setting as well as the plot line.

review_text: This was my first time buying a series. It worked perfectly on my Kindle but couldn't get it to play on my computer. As far as the show...loved it until today. Won't ever get involved in anything the eever have their hands in and anything else he is ever in I suggest we avoid like the plague. Actors seem to forget the only reason they are being offered other parts is because the character they're playing is loved by the pubic. Stabbing those fans in the back shouldn't be rewarded.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: While Season 3 of Downton Abbey is not as fabulous as the first two, the soap opera-esque writing still sucks you into the addictive show.  There are some great episodes and story lines in season 3 that make it worth watching including the wedding of the year and Sybil and family dynamics.  Of course, there is also more than a few boring stories that never seem to pick up speed (Bates Prison snoozefest).  The surprise ending seems like a lazy writer's solution to a casting issue.  I am not looking forward to the next season as I may have for past seasons.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Captivating storylines, incredible writing and character development.I couldn't wait to see this 3rd season after getting hooked watching the first 2 seasons for FREE on Prime Amazon.I was thrilled to have it available, even if I had to pay for this season of it! title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: It took me forever to start watching Downton Abbey despite being highly recommended by friends and colleagues. I was blown away by the clever and sophisticated writing, as well as the superb acting by the whole cast. Among the best series I've watched so far.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: First, I am NOT a fan of soap operas. Second,  I always found BBC/PBS shows rather rather bland.  Third, period pieces are not my favorites. Downton Abbey has trashed all three of those misconceptions.I tried an episode from season 2 under duress from my wife who heard of it from Jessica D. After that one episode, I was hooked.From the storyline through the ensemble, even the theme. Everything was exceptional. I was amazed at how stark the separation lines between the house and staff were. And yet the affection of the two for each other was obvious. The interaction between the two classes AND amongst themselves is the basis of the series and it succeeds immensely. Humor, sarcasm, intrigue, love, grief and many more emotions are expressed with realism and honesty.I wish I could express how captivating this show is without sounding like a studio flak but suffice it to say there is NOTHING about this show that I don't like.Zo!  Maybe this review is not a good candidate to base your decision on, butt "Try it." "You'll like it!"

However, Maggie Smith's character is awesome in all episodes, so an extra star for her.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Not given to soap opera in either UK or US contexts but wishing to oblige a dear one who had seen the first two years, I bit the bullet but kept iPad near to hand. Careful staging, meticulous costuming, and autos of the period,caught my attention.  Scripting faithful to perceptions, prejudices  and understandings of the time kept my attention.  I confess a prejudice in favor of actors trained in England and Ireland which fondness was not not at all undercut. In any vent, I wtched and enjoyed the whole thing.One tiny thing I wondered about that would have to do with Direction was the spectre of Shirley MacLaine at high table using dining implements as though a Brit. That such a wonderment arose is a tribute to how easily all else went to one not unfamiliar with the UK.
summary: latecomer to Downton Abbey thoroughly impressed

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I am a big fan of Downton Abbey with the multiple story lines and the sweep in time from the Edwardian era through WWI and the aftermath of the war with its profound efftect on previous social custom and norms.  The DVD lets you tune into that cast of characters and society so different from our time at any time.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Despite the show being consummately British in the tradition of Upstairs Downstairs and Coronation Street, each episode of Downton Abbey is packed with quickly-paced storyline and engaging characters (even the characters that bore you will eventually turn your head towards interest...and even empathy and endearment; Edith Crawley, in particular).  The only quarrel I have with it is that the show must  accommodate for actors who can't seem to commit to a show for longer than 3 years (but perhaps that's just the way some British serial actors work [see the Doctor Who series for that]), which means re-writing storylines to kill off or otherwise remove our favorite characters (I won't spoil anyone).  I still love and greatly recommend this show to anyone who loves period pieces.
summary: A soap opera of a different kind.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: It's an awesome show with interesting characters and story line. I would recommend it to anyone that likes dramas with historical perspective.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I've been avoiding spoilers for months, eagerly awaiting the return of Downton to the US while knowing that our British comrades get to return to the Abbey weeks in advance! I'm so glad Amazon is carrying the unedited British version of the show so we can enjoy it as intended.As the season is only a few episodes in, it's hard to rate it as a whole. The first few episodes have introduced a large quantity of drama, and Shirley Maclaine is a welcome and warm addition to the cast. Can't wait to see what happens!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: When this series started it quickly earned a well deserved reputation for a new style of period drama. It's success however has been it's undoing as the urge to keep it going long past its sell-by-date is leading it headlong down the slippery slope of ever more boring soap! This is most evident in the final "Trip to the Highlands" and for me it is rapidly losing its appeal despite looking better on Blu. Even the cast are fed up with it and are having to be eliminated in improbable story line twists as they say enough is enough! It is time to bring it to an end.
summary: From good drama to dreary soap!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Like most viewers of Downton Abbey I've been addicted to the series from the first episode of the first season.  The excellent cast, fine writing, and the wonderful sets and costumes make it a "Don't Miss" for me.  In Season 3 the noble Crawley family and their servants at Downton Abbey, having survived the vissitudes of World War I more or less intact, are faced with new economic and social pressures.  The world is changing, and the path is no longer automatically smoothed for bearers of noble titles and distinguished lineages.The Earl of Grantham gets things off to a rough start by mismanaging his wife Cora's wealth so badly that he loses it all and faces having to sell Downton Abbey.  His cousin, heir, and new son-in-law Matthew Crawley manages to sort things out in the end, but it's only the beginning. The Earl's daughters Mary (now married to Matthew at last), Edith, and Sybil all continue to have romantic ups and downs, while the Dowager Countess finds her place as Queen of Downton challenged by the arrival of Martha Levinson, the American mother of Lady Grantham. Below stairs the staff continues to soldier on, beset by scandal and romantic turmoils of their own. Eventually tragedy strikes both below and above stairs, leaving plenty of loose ends and questions that will lead to a Season 4 (and who knows how many more?)The fine cast headlined by Hugh Bonneville, Maggie Smith, Michelle Dockery, Penelope Wilton, and Jim Carter among many others has some stellar additions, most notably Shirley MacLaine.  Downton Abbey is over the top, sometimes campy, and with more plot twists and turns than any five or six other soap operas, but it's always sheer escapist fun.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Superbly written, directed and produced.  Casting is truly unparalleled as is the script.  Costumes, lighting, camera work and sets are worth watching even if the sound was turned off.  A great example of how to use the English language. This is a gem of a program that audiences of all ages will enjoy for the sheer art of viewing a masterpiece.  I was a season one skeptic, but by the end of the first three programs the character development had me hooked.  Now we eagerly await each episode and savor the entertainment of great writing and acting. We rarely recommend television programs, but this one deserves every accolade it has received.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I thought Season 3 was the best to date! We missed the last 3 episodes due to a trip, but watched the whole season 9 months later on Amazon Prime. This past September we were in Scotland and visited Inverary Castle. While there we saw a display about an episode of Downton Abbey being shot there. It ended up being the season 3 finale episode. It was so neat to think that we had just been there and had spent hours roaming around the house and grounds. But, the last scene almost ruined the whole episode. You'll have to watch it to see why.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: As a family we think the show is very well thought out and presented. It was a tremendous shock when Matthew was killed and we felt sad to see him go in such a way. The casting of the characters is superb and we follow them all with great interest. Of course, we are all pulling for Mr. Bates and Anna, Branson, and Matthew's mother. They seemed like underdogs a while back but now are such a big part of the show. It is a great offering and we all look forward to the next week's episode.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Downton Abbey has become a family favorite series. ALl my siblings (4) and my kids (2) love DA and we enjoy it in groups. I wish they produced more than 9 in a season. ALL TV should be this good!!!DA is a masterpiece of artistry in location, sets, lighting, production, directing, acting and storytelling. As a program director and videographer I really appreciate the exceptional visual quality, some of the camera moves are without equal. As one who hand held a video camera for a single 9 minute walk through yacht shot on Live TV I know how difficult it is to travel with a camera and rigging hanging from you. The photographers are constantly delighting us with extraordinary long moving shots that are so well staged and choreographed. Buy this series, it's awesome!!!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I was hooked on the series from the first episode.  The actors, in my opinion, are  perfect for the roles they play.  I love the story line.  I especially love the way they show the closeness of the family.  Showing the discipline of the household staff really gets the point across of what work ethic and loyalty is all about.  Lord Grantham, although an aristocrat, clearly shows what it is to be powerful and yet still be compassionate and reasonable.  I must admit that I was very disappointed that Mathew was killed of in the last episode of season three.  The bottom line is that we need more programs of this type.  Thanks.Joe CanzoneriApopka Florida

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Listen I was a late convert to the 'Downton' but I have been fully convert and am spreading the good news as much as possible. This show isn't just a flash in the pan but has some really good writing and acting. That being said with the amount of s*** that happens to this family, some of it brought on by their own actions but mainly from the outside world, it's getting tough to watch. I like to read and watch movies more as an escape and I don't find anything wrong with that so I'm not one who loves that 'it's painful just like real life'. This show hasn't gotten there but it's well on it's way and if you've watched all the other seasons and specials then you know what I'm talking about. All in all a very watchable and enjoyable series and I would whole-heartedly recommend getting or watching it.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This review is about the series itself.  Downton Abbey is a wonderful show that has developed some fantastic characters both honorable and admirable and also evil and conniving.  I've largely enjoyed the show  to this point, with a few exceptions.  Every now and then the writers will take a character and cause him or her to do something that is completely outside the scope and nature of that character.  This is where the show loses me.  If you establish, for example, that a man is honorable and will go down in flames before he will ever say a bad word about anyone else, then you can't have him blackmailing people in later episodes.  It just doesn't work.Season three started off okay, but ended terribly.  Toward the end of the story, the writers began to alter the characters taking some amazing ones and regressing them and taking one evil one and trying to suddenly make him into an honorable fellow and a hero.  It's not believable.  I'm not saying people can't change, but there needs to be a reasonable impetus or a change of philosophy before that change takes place.I love the setting.  I have come to love and admire some of the characters of this show.  But I quit.  The writers have killed it for me.  Watch season three at your own risk.  If you're anything like me, it will disappoint.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I started watching Downton Abbey last fall...so caught up on Amazon.  I recently visited England and was amazed that this is actually how it looks.  I stayed in a village in England and visited others.  I am totally in love with England, their customs and how they speak.  Watching Downton Abbey lets me revisit England and how I felt when I was there.  As well the characters on Downton Abbey are so well cast and I enjoy seeing the interaction between the social classes and the individuals in their own classes.  People are just people and we can see a bit of ourselves in all of them.  Excellent series.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Instead of talking about the plot, and giving away "spoilers" I will just say of all 4 seasons, season 3 is the most emotional, packing a punch and keeping you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.This is my family heritage as a descendant of the Spencers and relation to the current Earl of Spencer (who also shares the exact name of my father) at the Althrop estate (where Princess Diana is buried) This beautifully stunning series shows the transition of English aristocratic society from pre WWI up through by the end of season 3 the 1920s. The class differences of upstairs and downstairs is so convincingly portrayed by all the characters. You become invested in the plot, and feel they are some how your own family.The breathtaking historical accuracy to costumes, locations and English countryside alone is well worth tuning in for.Maggie Smith is hysterical with her witty banter as Violet, and I love all the characters.As a gay male myself, it is refreshing to see the development of Thomas Barrow's character played by Robert James Collier. Who handles the difficult role of a man inspiring to move up in social rank, devastated by WWI, and the horrific laws that were in effect in England against gay people.The love between Anna and Bates is both endearing and charming.J. R. is the author of:Lady Liberty: The Definitive Julie London HandbookandAn Historical Study of Kurt Weill's Der Silbersee: Ein WintermarchenThe shocking conclusion still leaves fans spellbound.  A must see.
summary: Sir Spencer gives a 5 star rating to Season 3 -Downton Abbey

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I have enjoyed Downton Abbey from Season 1. I own the DVDs for all three seasons. There are some sad twists to the Crawley story in Season 3, which I won't detail so as to avoid spoilers. The way Season 3 differs from the prior two seasons is this: when I re-watch Season 3, I skip over certain parts of the story. Though they are well dramatized and the acting is superb, the story line is too painful. I hope that Season 4 will find more members of the cast still with the show at season's end.
summary: A Dark Season 3 for Downton Abbey

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Each episode is a story unto itself whilst being a continuation in the saga of this family and its associated characters. Filmed on location in a superb setting, which makes for some historical accuracy not to mention eye candy, the series is a modern take on life of an aristocratic household and staff illustrating a social history of the period.Add to this the inevitable drama of three unmarried daughters and you have a modern-day soap with a lot of class!Written with warmth and wit by Julian Fellowes and with a well chosen casting, Downton Abbey proves to be an irresistible  concoction.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: The last episode is supremely depressing. They have had success incorporating tragedy into the show, I suppose that encouraged them to push it further. But with each successive tragedy becoming greater than the last, they over-reached in the end.I do not see myself watching the next season, if there even is one. In my mind the show has no further value to me. They had some great writing in this show, but they ended on such a sour note, it spoils the whole experience.
summary: I loved every episode... but the last ruined it.

review_text: Obviously, as a born and bred, red-blooded American raised in the rural southeast, I have no idea if this is truly how Brits from each tier of the class structure lived or not but I find the story line and life-challenges depicted in this series as truly fascinating. review_text: What they did to Crawley at the end blew my mind.  He saved the Lord and the estate and you crush him?  Something deeply psychological about that ending. Great acting makes this series art.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This cast, led by screen stalwarts Dame Maggie Smith and Hugh Bonneville, is outstanding from top to bottom.  It's rare that such a large troupe can hold a show together and keep people coming back week after week to follow the happenings, but this one does it.  While entirely fictional, it does use historical events and cultural norms from the time period to pepper the plots.  The writing is fine and consistent, even when external events (actors wanting to depart at the end of their contracts) force storylines.  Thus, we lose some loved characters, but gain new ones.I often find British dramas to be slow going and over-burdoned with heavy dialogue.  This one, however, bucks that trend.  Once the viewer gets acquainted with the characters, it is constantly fast-paced and interesting, jumping between multiple storylines, and utilizing the intricasies of each character's development, from conniving and twisted evil ones to lord of the manor ones.  It's simply fun, fun, fun.
summary: Great Cast, Non-stop Moving and Changing Stories

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3

Even the couple that seem to be parody/stereotypes are believable!They've killed off 2 major characters and 1 minor.  Two of them make sense, the third death was bad/rotten/unnecessary!As soon as I can figure out how to access season 4, i'm there!  Downton Abbey is even better than Upstairs/Downstairs.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: Love being able to watch episodes back-to-back.  The characters, plot and time period are all so intriguing.  I find it interesting that the servants are just as stoic and set in tradition as the aristocracy.  I am in the middle of season 3, and it is fun watching the change in the times and how some characters embrace it while others resist it.  It is amazing to me how people judge others and what they base their judgment on that has nothing to do with the real character of the person.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: My family and I cannot get enough of this show. We just love it.  We do find it odd that every time there is a pregnancy, there is some sort of tragedy that comes from it.  Either the child dies or a parent dies or someone is abandoned.  I was disappointed with the coverage of Mary's wedding. We watched her romance with Matthew over two whole seasons and we were all excited for the wedding in season three. With such a long build up I assumed the start of season 3 would be a lavish wedding. The wedding was over in the blink of the eye. No reception, no dancing, no fun conversations. That was odd too. Nonetheless we still tune in and still give the show a 5 star rating.
summary: Love it but find some oddities about it

I still love the show and am glad to have them, and will purchase seasons 1 and 2 as soon as possible. But it doesn't seem necessary to buy the UK version. review_text: From the period props to the excellent acting - could not stop seeing it! Can't wait for the next season. This constant play of classes keeps it shifting emotionally through the twisting plot lines.  WELL DONE BRITS !

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This entire series is incredibly well done in every way.  The acting is phenomenal, particularly the delivery of dry wit by Maggie Smith's Dowager Countess.  I used to watch this series with my husband, who very unexpectedly passed away at the age of 32 the night that we watch the last episode of this season.  For some time, I was unable to consider watching the show again.  But it is so well done that I couldn't stop, and was able to convince my parents to watch it with me instead.  Now they're both hooked too.  Lovers of period pieces, history, and drama will enjoy this immensely.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I did not watch Downton Abbey until my daughter in law insisted I watch. She downloaded Amazon Instant Video on my IPad and I was hooked from the very first episode.  I love being able to watch Series One, Two, and Three anytime either on my IPad or TV!  Being an Amazon Prime member, I was able to really enjoy the series as the storyline unfolded without waiting a week...or months to find out what happened next!  I am enthralled with each character, even the antagonists like Thomas.  Anna is a favorite but I am somewhat suspicious of Bates.  The deaths of William, Sybil, and my absolute favorite, Matthew, have hit me hard as if they were my family members.  I am ready to start Season Four and continue my obsession with Downton Abbey.  It will really be hard watching Season Five when it returns as I will then be stuck watching it from week to week.

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
reviewer_name: Kathy A. Pippig "Author of Shape-Shifter Books"
review_text: For quite awhile my brother and sister-in-law have been trying to get me interested in Downton Abbey. I didn't think it would appeal to me, but I put it in my Netflix lineup to watch later. However, Netflix removed it from their streaming selection completely before I had the opportunity to see any of it. While perusing Amazon's Instant Video selection I found they offered the first three seasons free to Prime Members. Recently, I thought I'd watch the first episode of season one and I became an immediate fan. I was addicted! I have been binge watching it and just finished the 3rd season. The 4th season cay be purchased at a good price from Amazon. After watching the last episode in season 3, I realized I HAD to see what happened next, and the rest is history. I have some more binge watching to do. LOL! This truly is a great show, all around - top notch acting, exquisite scenery and cinematography, award-winning writing, and gorgeous costumes complement the period-piece surroundings. What an absolute treat this show is.
summary: Hooked From Episode One - Season One

Reading reviews, the U.S. version has cut scenes, so I would recommend getting the UK Blueray version,plus are unable to play the UK DVD disc in our DVD players, so be sure to order the BlueRay version. title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: This series is an upgraded version of Upstairs, Downstairs.  Very good group of actors and cohesive story-tellking.  Maggie Smith simply tears up the scenery whenever she is part of the action!  It would be wise to start at the very first season and be sure to watch every Christmas show as well.  The third season keeps up with the quality and drama of seasons one and two...no shark jumping here!  Seems as if the quality control is on top of things as the vehicles and clothes seem pretty correct for the time depicted.  But the stories are the meat of the series and the stories are, like real life, full of ups and downs and surprises.  Just a gem of a show!
summary: Wonderful series, be sure to watch them all!

title: Masterpiece Classic: Downton Abbey Season 3
review_text: I was so looking forward to Season 3 of Downton Abbey. I thought Season 1 was wonderful and Season 2 was almost as good. So I waited for season 3 with baited breath, waiting to see what would happen to all my favorite characters. The first 2 episodes were great and the season seemed off to a promising start. Episodes 3 & 4 were good, though I thought that 4 was a little shaky plot wise. Episode 5 started out well and ended in being heartbreaking in the extreme, from there on out it was all downhill. By the time I finished watching the Christmas episode I was completely disillusioned. Gone was everything I had loved about the show.Originally Fellows said that Downton would only be 3 seasons and I wish that he had kept it that way because I think we would have gotten a FAR different story line. He let himself be talked out of his original plan, a plan that I suspect was fairly well thought out to begin with, and the resulting confusion and incoherency shows. This season was completely disjointed story wise, some plot lines were carried on infinitely longer than they needed to be (to the point where I was literally sick to death of them) and some were dropped before they were really even developed (the money "issues" being a prime example of this). There were even times when Fellows seemed have forgotten his own writing, apparently contradicting information he had given us in past seasons. But the worst was that the characters have morphed in ways that make them almost unrecognizable. I think if Season 1 Branson could see the Branson from the end of Season 3 or the Christmas special he'd drive the Crawley Renault right off a cliff. Perhaps Fellows was too busy working on his miniseries about the Titanic to truly care what was going on with Downton Abbey and since he has 2 more projects in the pipeline it seems unlikely that will change anytime in the near future. I am really left feeling that Fellows now views Downton as the cash cow to be used to finance his other projects and that is the saddest thing of all.The only reason I am giving Season 3 two stars is because the actors are still amazing and the costumes and locations continue to be gorgeous. Sadly neither of these makes me want to watch forthcoming seasons. So season 3 marks the end of my love affair with new episodes of this once great program though I will continue to cherish my copies of Seasons 1 & 2.
